üîó https://lnkd.in/g-7dx-PZ #IndigenomicsNOW #IndigenousEconomy #EconomicReconciliation #GlobalLeadership #Sustainability ‚Ä¶more 40 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Waawoono Consultancy 578 followers 3mo Report this post üì¢ "We're not just stakeholders; we're rights-holders." - Jason Rasevych ‚úä

First Nations communities must lead the way in Ontario's bioeconomy. Jason Rasevych, president of the Anishnawbe Business Professional Association (Northern Ontario) , powerfully stated at the Scaling Up Bioeconomy Conference | #ScalingUpBio that First Nations need to have ownership and leadership roles in this growing sector.

Why? Because they hold inherent rights to the land and its resources. Their traditional knowledge and practices are vital for sustainable resource management.

Let's amplify Indigenous voices and support their leadership in the bioeconomy! #IndigenousRights #Bioeconomy #Sustainability #Ontario Indigenous minds should shape bioeconomy: advocate chroniclejournal.com 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in NatureFinance 53,821 followers 8mo Report this post üçÉ Why is the bioeconomy important for both nature-rich countries and those with less biological diversity...

üå∫ The bioeconomy depends on biodiversity as its foundation, and biodiversity is essential for the processes that support all life on Earth.

üå¥ For example, the rainforests of the Amazon Basin and Congo Basin are globally important carbon sinks. 

üåç Since all countries benefit from the ecosystem services of nature, bioeconomy strategies can provide value to countries with different levels of biodiversity and technological development.

üü© For nature-rich countries, transitioning to a bioeconomy offers numerous opportunities for sustainable development by 

üî∫ Creating jobs,¬†
üî∫ Empowering vulnerable communities¬†
üî∫ Driving economic growth. 

üü¢ Vicente Ara√∫jo from the Brazilian Ministry of Foreign Affairs highlights that countries with less biological diversity often have a greater science and innovation capacity that can support the bioeconomy. 

üßÆ Therefore, the bioeconomy presents a broad investment landscape for technology, research and innovation, even for countries with limited natural capital. 

üáßüá∑ Vicente states that Brazil‚Äôs G20 Initiative on Bioeconomy aims to provide the international community with a tool that can help us address a multitude of global challenges. 

üìë A Global Stocktake Report details the bioeconomy strategy and practices of G20 members.

In this Foreword to our Special Issue on ‚ÄòInnovation Paradigms for Earth Systems Governance: Envisioning New Approaches to #Sustainability Transitions‚Äô Ameenah Gurib-Fakim , Former President of #Mauritius , discusses the #globalcrisis and the imminent exhaustion of the #biome . She reflects on the new ways that #society will need to function and how #empathy can bring about a more #sustainableworld . For Ameenah Gurib Fakim, the timing of this Special Issue could not be more appropriate.

Ameenah Gurib Fakim argues that ‚Äúwe are all going to have to invent a new world, decision by decision, action by action, over the coming decades‚Äù. #energytransition #climatechange #sustainabletransistions #empathy #sustainablegrowth #sustainability #unsdgs #CircularEconomy #GreenEconomy #sustainablebusiness #grandchallenges #socialinnovation #sustainableworld #unsdgs #sdgs #energytransformation #renewableenergy #lowcarbonenergysystems #biosphereintegrity #biospehere #earthbiocapacity #environmentalchallenges #grandchallenges #greenhousegas #carbonemissions #carbonfootprint #greenhousegasemission #innovation #innovationmanagement #digitaltransformation Dr. J√∂rn B√ºhring, PhD, MBA, SFHEA , Mika Aaltonen Lucy Kimbell Anne-Laure Mention Jo√£o Jos√© Pinto Ferreira Marko Torkkeli 11 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in UNEP-WCMC 80,116 followers 8mo Report this post üì£ Call for peer review!¬† 

Experts at UNEP-WCMC, in collaboration with Women4Biodiversity , have worked with partners to develop a new draft methodology for an indicator to track progress towards Target 23 of the #GBF . 

The indicator helps Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity ( UN Biodiversity ) to comprehensively measure progress towards the national implementation of the CBD Gender Plan of Action, which will significantly contribute to the achievement of Target 23. üåø  

Parties and observers are invited to participate in this peer review and share feedback to help refine and finalise the indicator methodology in time for #COP16 üìÜ Last day to submit the review: 23 August 2024

Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 4w Report this post #indigenomics in action #indigenouseconomy Gene Ouellette Making things happen 4w Building Indigenous Economic Growth Through Procurement

Attended the City of Regina Indigenous Procurement Business Gathering, where the City reaffirmed its commitment to increasing Indigenous participation in procurement. With a 20% target, they‚Äôre actively working to create more opportunities for Indigenous businesses.

On a national level, the Federal Government‚Äôs 5% Indigenous Procurement Policy represents a potential $22.5B annual investment in Indigenous enterprises. While targets haven‚Äôt been fully met, the momentum is undeniable.

Procurement is a powerful tool for economic development, job creation, and self-sufficiency in Indigenous communities. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1mo Report this post #indigenomics in action #indigenous economy First Nations Finance Authority 7,936 followers 1mo NISICHAWAYASIHK CREE NATION INVESTS $10M IN FNFA BOND 

‚ÄúInvesting in FNFA‚Äôs bond program aligns with our long-term vision of self-sufficiency and sustainable growth,‚Äù said Chief Angela Levasseur of Nisichawayasihk Cree Nation. ‚ÄúThis investment will enable us to undertake critical projects that enhance the quality of life for our members and promote economic prosperity. Being able to assist in funding Indigenous-led projects across Canada demonstrates our solidarity with all First Nation communities in Canada.‚Äù

Since its inaugural bond issuance in 2014, FNFA has successfully raised over $3 billion in financing for First Nations governments generating an estimate of 30,000 jobs and $6.5 billion to the national economic output while supporting a wide range of projects from public infrastructure and housing to green energy initiatives.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D‚Äôs Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Edited Report this post The enduring impact of colonization has significantly shaped our modern economic perspectives, leading to displacement and a persistent socio-economic gap among Indigenous peoples. However, the time has come for us to reclaim our narrative and strategically craft a future that aligns with the Indigenous economic worldview.

With the resurgence of business, entrepreneurship, and nation-building, there arises a crucial need for a dedicated space to focus on designing and healing our relationship with money.

üå± Indigenomics DESIGN: Indigenous Wealth Dynamics üå±
City: Saskatoon (venue to be announced)
Date: June 4th, 2024

This conference serves as a pivotal platform for dialogue on systematically transforming our approach to money, finance, commerce, investment, and capital markets. It is a forum for strategic healing and visionary design critical for the prosperity and sustainability of Indigenous communities.

Let's unite to forge a path towards a future where prosperity is deeply rooted in our cultural heritage, guided by Indigenous wisdom, and propelled by strategic innovation.

Title: Marwa Abdou's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Feb 26, 2023  ¬∑  Indigenomics Institute #economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub. No¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub | Marwa Abdou Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Marwa Abdou‚Äôs Post Marwa Abdou Senior Research Director | Advisory | Public Policy | Inclusive & Sustainable Development | Advocacy | Storytelling | Data Analysis 2y Edited Report this post Just before the holidays, Stephen Tapp, PhD gifted our team five books to offer inspiration for 2023. It didn't take long before I leapt towards Carol Anne Hilton, MBA 's ‚ÄúIndigenomics ‚Äì taking a seat at the table‚Äù and finally got around to reading it this weekend. 

If Economics as a discipline is about understanding behavior around our world‚Äôs limited resources, then Indigenomics should be a field of study on its own under that umbrella. For all economic practitioners. Indigenous lands are estimated to make up around¬†20%¬†of the world‚Äôs territory, containing 80% of its remaining biodiversity (IISD). And, my guess is these are very conservative estimates as they don‚Äôt include unceded lands and territories. 

In 2011, TD Economics estimated that the size of the indigenous economy in Canada would eclipse $32 billion by 2016. That number has since grown 1.5 X ‚Äì expected to reach 100 billion by 2025. And yet, indigenous voices remain excluded (alongside numerous others).

Intersectionality is crucial in storytelling. It‚Äôs also fundamental in building a more connected understanding of the world. Making progress in today‚Äôs world requires us dig into and engage with multiple identities and perspectives simultaneously. Unfortunately, as humans we are wired to seek neatly defined boxes and checklists. It gives us a sense of security and comfort. But we‚Äôre way past the point (or at least should be) of one-dimensional invitations or assigned seats. Representation can‚Äôt be just about proportions because identities are complex and the world we live in requires agility and dynamism. So, perhaps that means that the table and the criteria around it needs to be scrapped, reimagined, and rebuilt, rather than just extended.

While it‚Äôs a broad lens, there is a lot in this work that is transferable. As Hilton says Indigenomics is about ‚Äúour relationship to ourselves, to each other, to the Earth, to our past, and our future‚Äù. 

All in all, this book didn‚Äôt disappoint. One that I wish existed (and was required) when I was a student. I hope it will have follow on work that digs further and more explicitly into the data and policy side of things. Title: Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D on LinkedIn: #indigenomics ...
Description: Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #indigenouseconomy | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D‚Äôs Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1mo Report this post #indigenomics in action #indigenouseconomy Keith Henry President and Chief Executive Officer at Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) 1mo Thank you Sam Laskaris and Windspeaker Media for the story about the current economic results regarding #Indigenous tourism in Canada as produced by the The Conference Board of Canada released this month. 

This is the most accurate media coverage about the concerns facing the Indigenous tourism industry that I have read so far.

Key takeaways:

1.  Non Indigenous tourism has surpassed 2019 tourism revenues as of 2023, reaching 113 billion in total revenues.  Was worth an estimated 105 billion in 2019.  
2.  Indigenous tourism remains well below the 2019 economic levels (was our best year ever).  The total is 3.7 billion as of the end of 2023 which remains 8% lower that 2019.  
3. More Indigenous tourism businesses than ever,  but less revenues overall.  
4.  Staffing remains a major challenge and is 5% less than 2019. 
5.  Growth projected due to the high domestic and international visitor demands, but Indigenius tourism will not meet revenues and job creation potential without key investments and still remain below 2019 levels. 
6.  Federal investments for our sector continue to decline and will reach the lowest level of Federal government support for our industry since 2017 in 2025. 

This remains a major concern to our leadership and team Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) We continue to create solutions but need partners to show tangible support as well. 

Go to this link to read the entire story. https://lnkd.in/grWXw3vB #2025iitc #DestinationIndigenous #indigenoustourism #ITDF #TheOriginalOriginal #indigenous #firstnations #metis #inuit 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Tourism Industry Association of Canada 30,003 followers 11mo Report this post As the Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) celebrates #TourismWeekCanada2024 , let's recognize the incredible impact the Indigenous Tourism sector has had and continues to have on Canada. 

As of 2019, Indigenous tourism in Canada boasted over 39,000 workers and comprised more than 1,900 Indigenous tourism businesses, contributing $1.9 billion annually to Canada‚Äôs direct GDP (up $1.5 billion in 2017). Moreover, it generated $1.1 billion in wages and salaries, and revenue generated $3.7 billion, showcasing its potential for growth and sustainability.  

More good news! In 2024, Indigenous tourism will  directly contribute a total of $800M in tax revenues to all three levels of government in Canada. 

Indigenous tourism is poised for even greater success. Strategic priorities have been outlined in Canada 365, the 2023 Federal Tourism Growth Strategy, and ITAC‚Äôs ambitious 2030 Vision to make Canada the world leader in Indigenous tourism. 

Download the Fact Sheet: https://ow.ly/5Vjx50RhucI #TheOriginalOriginal #IndigenousTourism #IndigenousTourismTeamCanada 35 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous SME Business Magazine 1,176 followers 8mo Report this post The Rise of Indigenous-Led Tourism in Canada!

Indigenous-led tourism is transforming Canada's tourism landscape, highlighting the strength and resourcefulness of Indigenous peoples. With a substantial CAD 25 billion investment from the federal government, this sector is set to thrive, offering genuine cultural experiences and promoting sustainable development. The Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) plays a pivotal role, fostering collaboration among associations, governments, and industry leaders. This growth not only boosts the economy and preserves Indigenous traditions but also fosters reconciliation and self-determination. By 2030, the industry aims to add 85,000 jobs and elevate Canada on the global tourism stage.

Read more at https://lnkd.in/gSrDy-4r Subscribe to the Indigenous-SME Business Magazine at https://lnkd.in/gBMWGCHX #IndigenousTourism #CanadaTourism #CulturalHeritage 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Shae Bird Tourism executive building destinations for community and the visitor economy. 1mo Report this post This latest economic research from Conference Board of Canada tells a lot about the Indigenous tourism economy across Canada, but for Alberta it highlights the resilience, leadership and alignment throughout this province. While the rest of the country continues on its journey to reach pre-covid impacts, Alberta has not only recovered but increased Direct GDP by an astounding 66% going from $141.1m (2019) to $234.2m (2023). 

 I am grateful to have been involved in such important work and look forward to watching Indigenous Tourism Alberta's continued success alongside all their partners. 

1) Conference Board of Canada (2025). Indigenous tourism sector impact in canada - January 2025. retrieved from https://lnkd.in/gJ8n3ArV 2) Conference Board of Canada (2023). The Economic Impact of Covid-19 Pandemic on Indigenous Tourism Businesses in Alberta. Retrieved from https://lnkd.in/ghkd23Yq Indigenous Tourism Alberta Travel Alberta David F. Goldstein Darren Reeder Joseph Schow Brenda Holder Tom Babin Jaspar Ndlovu, CPA Carrie Armstrong 74 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) 10,335 followers 5mo Report this post The Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) is pleased to announce the release of its 2023-24 Annual Report. The new look of the report highlights ITAC‚Äôs continued success in supporting its record-breaking year for members and the advancement of Indigenous tourism from coast to coast to coast.¬†
f
In the 2023-24 fiscal year, ITAC introduced new programs aimed at fostering long-term growth while maintaining a balanced budget. Notable national achievements include the launch of the Truth2Action Training, a reconciliation program for the tourism industry, and the Indigenous Tourism Destination Fund, which surpassed its target by raising $232,000.

To date, the Indigenous Tourism Fund's Micro and Small Business Stream, supported by the Government of Canada, has provided $3.7 million in critical funding to 145 Indigenous tourism businesses nationwide.

Read more and download #AnnualReport - https://lnkd.in/gTRJDqic #DestinationIndigenous #TheOriginalOriginal #IndigenousTourism #Tourism 30 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ken Rochat President at Big Sky Media 7mo Report this post Navigating the tourism tides: Alberta's journey post-pandemic
The pandemic significantly disrupted many economic sectors, with tourism being one of the hardest hit. In May 2019, almost 100,189 non-resident travelers entered Canada via Alberta. 
It wasn't until May 2023 that the number of tourists entering Canada via Alberta returned to pre-pandemic levels.
 
The number of non-resident visitors entering Canada via Alberta over the first five months of 2024 (latest data available) was 14.5% higher than over the same period in 2023.* 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in ACOA - APECA 17,285 followers 5mo Report this post Tourism is vital to Atlantic Canada‚Äôs economy and long-term prosperity. The sector generates economic benefits across the region, in communities large and small, in major centres, and in rural and remote areas.‚ÄØ
Through Elevate, the Government of Canada will increase commercial tourism investments in Atlantic Canada to $25 million over 2 years. 

New and returning visitors to Atlantic Canada are looking for authentic cultural and experiential offerings unique to the region. Tourism businesses across the four Atlantic provinces already offer world-class products and services. With this targeted support, more businesses can elevate their offerings to attract even more visitors.  

Is your tourism business ready to increase yield and attract new visitors? Learn more: https://ow.ly/jBPp50TOtRb #ElevateTourism #GC 3 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Edge Business Expo 90 followers 6mo Report this post Exciting Grant Opportunity for Tourism Growth!

Get all the information here https://lnkd.in/d2jvse4U #PrairiesCanFunded #ManitobaBusiness #TourismGrowth #CanadaTourism #FundingOpportunity Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Global Opportunities "Canadian Immigration Firm" 44,541 followers 2mo Report this post The provincial government‚Äôs commitment to boosting tourism has played a significant role in this achievement. In 2023 alone, Nova Scotia invested over $4 million in marketing and tourism product development. These efforts resulted in impressive visitor numbers, with over 2.2 million visitors recorded throughout 2023 and more than one million arrivals between January and July 2024. Read more about it in https://buff.ly/2X9wEUS #torontoimmigrationconsultant #immigrationconsultants #immigrationconsultant 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Travel Penticton 982 followers 11mo Report this post A high proportion of BC residents (79%) agree that tourism creates career opportunities, is an important investment in growing BC's economy/communities (79%) and generates substantial tax revenues (78%). All age groups ‚Äì over 55 (98%), 35-54 (94%), and 18-24 (86%) ‚Äì believe the tourism industry is important to British Columbia's economy. #TourismWeekCanada2024 #BCTourismCounts Tourism Industry Association of BC (TIABC) // Destination British Columbia 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) 10,335 followers 2mo Edited Report this post #PressRelease : New Conference Board of Canada Research Shows Indigenous Tourism‚Äôs Potential Falling Short of Post-Covid Recovery Goals Despite Growing Demand

Indigenous tourism has yet to return to pre-pandemic levels (in 2019), with inflationary pressures and workforce shortages serving as the key contributors, according to an economic report conducted by the The Conference Board of Canada (CBOC) and the Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) .

The report underscores the critical role Indigenous tourism plays in Canada‚Äôs economy. In 2023, Indigenous tourism directly contributed $1.6 billion to Canada‚Äôs GDP ‚Äì a decrease of 10 per cent compared to 2019, and an even greater decrease of nearly 24 per cent when adjusted for inflation.

Despite the downturn, Indigenous tourism in Canada generated an estimated $3.7 billion in revenues in 2023. Moreover, Indigenous tourism‚Äôs total direct economic impact supported more than 34,700 jobs and contributed close to $730 million in direct government revenue (federal, provincial, and municipal).

‚ÄúLooking ahead to 2025 and beyond, it will be more important than ever for our federal, territorial, and provincial partners to come together and collectively support the ongoing recovery of Indigenous tourism,‚Äù says Keith Henry , CEO and president at ITAC. ‚ÄúThis report highlights the sector‚Äôs positive impact on Canada‚Äôs economy ‚Äì and for Indigenous businesses across the country to thrive and reach pre-pandemic levels, ongoing and long-term investment is vitally important to the sector‚Äôs success.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe tourism sector is also facing greater inflationary pressures than other sectors,‚Äù said Alan Chaffe, PhD , Associate Director of Economic Research at The Conference Board of Canada. ‚ÄúPrices for tourism-related goods and services in 2023 were an estimated 18.8 per cent higher than in 2019‚Äîexceeding the economy-wide inflation rate of 15.5 per cent over the same¬†period.‚Äù

Title: Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D on LinkedIn
Description: Jan 21, 2025  ¬∑  It's time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions.
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #economicreconciliation #indigenousleadership‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D‚Äôs Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 2mo Report this post "It‚Äôs time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions, knowledge, and sovereignty."

As Indigenous peoples, we are not just participants in the economy; we are architects of a system that reflects our interconnectedness, sustainability, and collective prosperity. Economic justice means recognizing our inherent rights, fostering economic reconciliation, and creating pathways for economic sovereignty that benefit all.

We are witnessing a transformative era where Indigenous businesses, entrepreneurs, and nations are reclaiming their rightful place at the economic table. The future is being shaped by Indigenous leadership, collaborative partnerships, and a vision that respects the land, our values, and our people.

Let‚Äôs continue to fuel this momentum. Who wants to play Indigenomics?
Email info@indigenomics.com for sponsorship opportunities. #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousLeadership #IndigenousWealth #EconomicJustice #Sovereignty #FutureOfIndigenousEconomies #TogetherWeThrive 89 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Donald (Don) Bartlett President at B6 Consulting Inc 2mo Report this comment Awesome!üëè Thanks Like Reply 1¬†Reaction Winona Lafreniere Community Builder / Creative Solutionist / Indigenous Wellness Advocate 2mo Report this comment You model collaboration and cultural respect Carol-Anne. This is what empowers purposeful dialogue, partnerships, and understanding in 2025 (and onward).üß° Like Reply 8¬†Reactions 9¬†Reactions See more comments To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1mo Edited Report this post Get ready‚ÄîRegistration for Indigenomics IMPACT is opening soon! 

As part of the groundbreaking Indigenomics series, this dynamic gathering is designed to celebrate and advance real success within the Indigenous economy. This is where economic reconciliation takes action.

Over two transformative days, we will spotlight:
-Groundbreaking Indigenous partnerships
-Innovative businesses and investments
-Policies driving economic reconciliation
-Success stories that showcase Indigenous economic strength

This is where Indigenous-led solutions, business excellence, and investment meet to activate the full potential of the $100 billion Indigenous economy.

Be part of the movement. Registration opens soon!
üì© Sign up for updates: https://lnkd.in/g67cpagb #IndigenomicsIMPACT #IndigenousEconomy #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousLeadership #FutureofIndigenomics #IndigenousBusiness 11 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenomics 4,887 followers 4mo Edited Report this post Learn from Garry Oker, MA and Tasha Brooks as they dive into economic models that prioritize sustainability, community well-being, and long-term prosperity. Each speaker will present insights into how Indigenous knowledge forms the foundation of economic strategies that honor both people and planet.

Discover how Indigenous knowledge is driving economic change‚Äîsign up today!

Register now for Indigenomics NOW and gain year-round access to the content for as low as $50 USD. https://lnkd.in/gjspHVwS #Indigenomics #IndigenousEconomy #IndigenomicsNOW #ResilientEconomies #Globaleconomy 63 4 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenomics 4,887 followers 2mo Report this post The Indigenomics Institute is thrilled to invite leading companies and organizations to take part in the first session of the Indigenomics 50 challenge in Vancouver on April 7, 2025, for a transformative journey towards meaningful economic reconciliation. Through the Indigenomics LEGO Design Sessions, participants will develop actionable Reconciliation Action Plans (RAPs) that integrate Indigenous economic inclusion, cultural respect, and lasting partnerships into their core business strategies.

By participating, organizations will:
üîπ Gain insights into Indigenous economic frameworks rooted in reciprocity, respect, and interconnectedness.
üîπ Co-design actionable strategies that contribute to the rising Indigenous economy.
üîπ Build meaningful partnerships with Indigenous leaders, businesses, and communities to advance economic reconciliation in tangible ways.
üîπJoin a network of forward-thinking companies actively shaping the future of the $100 billion Indigenous economy.

This is your opportunity to take action, drive change, and make reconciliation a priority.

üì© Register now at info@indigenomics.com ‚Äì Limited spots available!

Breaking away from the dependency model is crucial, and events like these offer vital opportunities to reshape the future of economic reconciliation. I‚Äôm inspired by the conversations happening here and the collective drive to create sustainable, inclusive economic growth for Indigenous nations. #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousEconomies #IndianAct #Empowerment #Leadership 15 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Chemonics International 328,835 followers 2mo Report this post üåçüí° Access to affordable financial services is a critical driver for tackling global poverty and fostering long-term economic growth. Learn more in President and CEO Jamey Butcher‚Äôs new article for Forbes below ‚¨áÔ∏è Jamey Butcher President and CEO at Chemonics International 2mo Business and #SustainableDevelopment leaders have a unique opportunity‚Äîand responsibility‚Äîto make a transformative impact on the future of global poverty and economic growth. One of the most effective ways to create lasting impact is by advancing #financial inclusion globally, ensuring that everyone, regardless of where they live, has access to essential financial services.
¬†
At Chemonics International , we‚Äôve seen firsthand how impactful financial inclusion can be. For example, in the #Philippines , where we have a long history of advancing financial inclusion, we launched Higala in partnership with Talino Venture Studios to help reach millions of unbanked people in the country. Higala will ultimately make digital transactions more accessible and affordable for rural banks and their customers.
¬†
In a new article I penned for Forbes , learn more about the importance of #FinancialInclusion and my advice for how leaders can help support it, such as:
¬†
üí° Understand the needs of unbanked and underbanked populations.
üí° Adopt know-your-customer ( #KYC ) practices.
üí° Innovate with scalable, accessible financial services. https://lnkd.in/gF3cwCqw Council Post: Why Financial Inclusion Is Critical‚ÄîAnd How Businesses Can Support It social-www.forbes.com 38 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Jamey Butcher President and CEO at Chemonics International 2mo Report this post Business and #SustainableDevelopment leaders have a unique opportunity‚Äîand responsibility‚Äîto make a transformative impact on the future of global poverty and economic growth. Senior Vice President at Chemonics International 2mo Edited Report this post üí° Did you know that 1.4 billion people worldwide still lack access to basic financial services? Achieving #FinancialInclusion is a key enabler for the Sustainable Development Goals ( #SDGs ), not only helping people meet basic needs but also enabling global economic growth and resilience.  

In a new article for Forbes , Chemonics International President and CEO Jamey Butcher shares insights about the importance of financial inclusion, highlights Chemonics‚Äô 50 years of experience in advancing it through our mission-driven work, and some of the strategies leaders can leverage to support it.  

 ‚ÄúTo solve problems globally, we need to invest in local communities and innovators. Infrastructure for transformative change already exists‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs just a matter of private sector partners, governments, and beyond working together to fill the gaps.‚Äù 

Learn more at the link below! ‚¨áÔ∏è Council Post: Why Financial Inclusion Is Critical‚ÄîAnd How Businesses Can Support It social-www.forbes.com 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Francis Bosah üî¨Soil Health | Regenerative Agriculture Missionary + Thought-Leader + Educator + Communicator + Coach + Mentor + Board Advisor 2mo Edited Report this post ü¶Åüå¥ Prioritizing Afro-Regenerative Roots 

Any African ag interventional strategy, regardless of its origin, must prioritize an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift as its foundational framework. This is not optional, but indispensable.

Decades of well-intentioned yet flawed interventions,often rooted in colonial ag's legacy of exploitation & dispossession,have yielded limited impact, perpetuating systemic inequalities & ecological degradation.

It's time to acknowledge that:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Business-as-usual approaches, modeled after colonial-era export-oriented ag, have come up short, failing to address the complex, interconnected challenges facing African ag.

2Ô∏è‚É£ External solutions imposed without African ownership & agency, echoing the paternalistic attitudes of colonial powers, have often exacerbated problems,undermining local knowledge & resilienceüíî

3Ô∏è‚É£ Incremental reforms & technical fixes, reminiscent of the "modernization" efforts of colonial ag, are insufficient; transformative, systemic change is requiredüî•

Even when regen models are introduced, they often fall short of being truly systemic, neglecting to:

üå±Address the historical power imbalances & injustices perpetuated by colonialism & neoliberalism.

üåø Incorporate African indigenous knowledge,cultural heritage & ancestral wisdom.

üåªPrioritize African-led solutions, self-determination & community-driven development.

By realigning interventions around an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift, we can:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Center African voices, perspectives & leadership in ag development, reclaiming the narrative from colonial-era stereotypes

2Ô∏è‚É£ Foster self-determination, community-driven solutions & collective prosperity, redressing the historical injustices of colonial ag

3Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivate Afro-ecological resilience, ensuring sustainable, regen & climate-resilient ag practices,a stark departure from the exploitative practices of colonial ag.

This shift:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Recognizes & respects African indigenous knowledge, cultural heritage, & ancestral wisdom,long suppressed by colonial powers

2Ô∏è‚É£ Addresses the historical injustices & power imbalances perpetuated by colonialism & neoliberalism, acknowledging the ongoing impacts of colonial ag

3Ô∏è‚É£ Prioritizes African-led solutions, self-determination & community-driven development, a radical departure from the top-down approaches of colonial ag

By integrating an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift, interventions can:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Avoid perpetuating neocolonialism & extractive practices, instead promoting African-led, Afro-centric solutions

2Ô∏è‚É£ Foster genuine partnerships & collaborations that center African voices & perspectives,rather than imposing external "expertise"

3Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivate Afro-ecological resilience, ensuring sustainable & regen ag practices, a testament to the ingenuity & resilience of #Africanfarmers .

It's time to co-create a new pathway, one that honours African agency, wisdom & resilience.

Let's amplify Afro-regenerative systemic change! 39 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 20,741 followers 3000+ Posts View Profile Follow Explore topics Sales Marketing IT Services Business Administration HR Management Engineering Soft Skills See All LinkedIn ¬© 2025 About Accessibility User Agreement Privacy Policy Cookie Policy Copyright Policy Brand Policy Guest Controls Community Guidelines ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ© (Arabic) ‡¶¨‡¶æ‡¶Ç‡¶≤‡¶æ (Bangla) ƒåe≈°tina (Czech) Dansk (Danish) Deutsch (German) ŒïŒªŒªŒ∑ŒΩŒπŒ∫Œ¨ (Greek) English (English) Espa√±ol (Spanish) ŸÅÿßÿ±ÿ≥€å (Persian) Suomi (Finnish) Fran√ßais (French) ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä (Hindi) Magyar (Hungarian) Bahasa Indonesia (Indonesian) Italiano (Italian) ◊¢◊ë◊®◊ô◊™ (Hebrew) Êó•Êú¨Ë™û (Japanese) ÌïúÍµ≠Ïñ¥ (Korean) ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä (Marathi) Bahasa Malaysia (Malay) Nederlands (Dutch) Norsk (Norwegian) ‡®™‡©∞‡®ú‡®æ‡®¨‡©Ä (Punjabi) Polski (Polish) Portugu√™s (Portuguese) Rom√¢nƒÉ (Romanian) –†—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π (Russian) Svenska (Swedish) ‡∞§‡±Ü‡∞≤‡±Å‡∞ó‡±Å (Telugu) ‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏©‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏ó‡∏¢ (Thai) Tagalog (Tagalog) T√ºrk√ße (Turkish) –£–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—Å—å–∫–∞ (Ukrainian) Ti·∫øng Vi·ªát (Vietnamese) ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá (Chinese (Simplified)) Ê≠£È´î‰∏≠Êñá (Chinese (Traditional)) Language Sign in to view more content Create your free account or sign in to continue your search Sign in Welcome back Email or phone Password Show Forgot password? Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 6mo Report this post As Indigenous businesses continue to rise, the opportunity for meaningful partnerships, sustainable growth, and economic reconciliation has never been greater. Indigenomics on BAY STREET provides corporate leadership opportunities to forge meaningful partnerships, gain strategic insights, and actively contribute to the growth of the Indigenous economy.

-Drive Inclusive Growth: Collaborating with Indigenous businesses enhances diversity, strengthens supply chains, and creates shared prosperity.

-Champion Economic Reconciliation: Supporting the Indigenous economy is not just a responsibility‚Äîit's a strategic advantage in building a more equitable and resilient future.

-Invest in Sustainability: Indigenous-led projects are at the forefront of sustainable practices, offering innovative solutions that benefit both the environment and the economy.

Bring your leadership to Indigenomics on BAY STREET to connect with Indigenous leaders, explore investment opportunities, and be part of shaping the future of Canada's economy.

Register before September 18 to secure your spot and take the first step toward contributing to the transformative growth of the Indigenous economy. https://lnkd.in/geMXdZPA #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #Leadership #Sustainability #IndigenousEconomy #IndigenomicsOnBayStreet ‚Ä¶more 14 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Tebby V. Olatetse Accounting MajorI United World Colleges Scholar| Sales Associate at Garage Clothing |
Passionate about Finance, Sales, and Global Education 5mo Edited Report this post Yesterday, I had the privilege of attending the Economic Reconciliation in the Workplace workshop, part of the Canadian Chamber‚Äôs 2024 Inclusive Growth Dialogue Series üåç, in collaboration with the Greater Nanaimo Chamber of Commerce and Vancouver Island Economic Alliance . Hearing from Erralyn Joseph , Desiree Baker, Kear Portris, and Trevor Cootes, made me realize how essential it is to champion long-term growth through meaningful collaborations. It was an insightful and inspiring event that deepened my understanding of the critical role economic reconciliation plays in advancing inclusive growth.

Here are my three key takeaways:

Economic reconciliation is about actionable change‚ÄîIt‚Äôs more than just inclusion. It‚Äôs about creating sustainable, equitable opportunities for Indigenous communities to thrive through meaningful partnerships and support. ü§ù

Businesses have a pivotal role‚ÄîFrom inclusive hiring practices to supporting Indigenous-led initiatives, organizations have the power to drive lasting change by embedding reconciliation into their culture and operations. üè¢

Education and mentorship are powerful tools‚ÄîInvesting in Indigenous entrepreneurship, providing mentorship, and sharing resources are essential steps toward building a more inclusive and resilient economy. üìö

I‚Äôm excited to take these lessons forward and contribute to tangible progress in my own work. How is your organization advancing economic reconciliation? I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts and ideas. #EconomicReconciliation #InclusiveGrowth #IndigenousLeadership #WorkplaceEquity #ChamberEvents #Nanaimo #ReconciliationInAction #GrowthMindset 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Bay of Plenty Business News 2,076 followers 7mo Report this post Priority One and Te Waka call on the government to join forces with local leaders to develop a united strategy for strengthening the Golden Triangle. Coordinated investment in Waikato and Western Bay of Plenty is key to driving export economies and New Zealand's future wellbeing. Priority One Western Bay of Plenty | Te Waka: Waikato's Regional Economic Development Agency Call for government to unlock the Western Bay‚Äôs potential - Bay of Plenty Business News https://bopbusinessnews.co.nz 22 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Forward Summit 9,288 followers 2mo Report this post What is Indigenous Economic Reconciliation?

It‚Äôs more than a concept‚Äîit‚Äôs a call to action. It‚Äôs about ensuring Indigenous communities have the opportunity to fully participate in and benefit from the economy by breaking down systemic barriers and building meaningful partnerships.

Four key areas for economic reconciliation are:
1Ô∏è‚É£  Partnerships & Collaborations
2Ô∏è‚É£  Capacity Building
3Ô∏è‚É£  Inclusive Policies
4Ô∏è‚É£  Investment in Communities

Forward Summit incorporates these key focuses when bringing together Indigenous and non-Indigenous leaders to drive progress for economic reconciliation.

Need a reason for why it matters? Here are a few: 
üü¢  Unlocks Canada‚Äôs economic potential
üü¢  Advances equity and justice
üü¢  Strengthens industries with Indigenous values and innovation

-- What innovative approaches or collaborations have you seen that support Indigenous economic reconciliation? Share by commenting below! üëá -- #ForwardSummit #ForwardSummit2025 #EconomicReconciliation #SharedProsperity #CommunityInvestment #EmpowerChange 51 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Michelle Tierney Non-Executive Director | ASX | NZX | Govt | NFP 10mo Report this post Researchers at the University of Melbourne‚Äôs Dilin Duwa Centre for Indigenous Business Leadership
show in the 2021-22 financial year, Indigenous businesses generated $16.1 billion in revenue, around the same as the Australian timber industry, and provided jobs for 116,795 employees. 

‚ÄúThis is no small contribution, especially when considering that much of the employment is in regional and remote Australia.‚Äù

‚ÄúStarting from little if any intergenerational wealth, starting from low-to-no homeownership, starting from a challenging pipeline into higher education and access to resourceful social networks, the progress of many is astounding.‚Äù

‚ÄúEconomically engaging and building up Indigenous businesses is working‚Ä¶ We all win with the advancement of Indigenous economic self-determination.‚Äù #self -determination #IndigenousBusiness #economicempowerment @MichelleEvans @CainPolidano The great success story of Indigenous enterprise is missing afr.com 3 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SODECO SARL DRC Society for the development of Congo 10mo Edited Report this post Calling All Experts: Help Shape a Groundbreaking Book on Transformative Leadership for African Development

 Esteemed Colleagues,
 I am embarking on an ambitious and timely book project that aims to redefine the landscape of sustainable development in Africa. Titled "Transformative Leadership for Reimagining African Futures: Towards Sustainable and Equitable Development," this pioneering work will present a bold, interdisciplinary framework for catalyzing transformative change across the African continent. As a scholar and practitioner in the field of African development, I am seeking to tap into the wealth of knowledge, diverse perspectives, and innovative ideas within our global community. I invite you - the experts, scholars, policymakers, and development practitioners - to contribute your insights and expertise to this landmark publication. Some of the key themes and questions we will explore include:
 1. Rethinking Development Paradigms: What are the shortcomings of existing development frameworks in Africa, and how can we design more holistic, equitable, and environmentally-sustainable approaches? 
 2. Harnessing the Power of Transformative Leadership: What are the essential characteristics, competencies, and enabling conditions for African leaders to cultivate a shared vision, empower marginalized communities, and drive systemic change? 
 3. Scaling Up Community-Driven Initiatives: How can we learn from and scale up innovative, community-led projects that harness renewable energy, promote agroecological farming, empower women and youth, and revitalize traditional knowledge systems? 
 4. Forging Multi-Stakeholder Collaboration: How can policymakers, civil society leaders, and community organizers work in tandem to align development efforts with the Sustainable Development Goals?
 5. Advancing Theoretical and Practical Frameworks: How can we synthesize cutting-edge theories from development studies, political economy, environmental science, and leadership studies to develop a transformative new paradigm for African development? If you are passionate about redefining the future of Africa and contributing to this landmark publication, I encourage you to reach out to me directly. I am particularly interested in hearing from those with expertise in any of the aforementioned areas, as well as those who can offer insights from the unique socio-cultural, political, and environmental contexts of different African regions. Together, let us embark on this transformative journey and co-create a bold, visionary framework that will shape the development discourse and inspire tangible change across the African continent. I look forward to your engagement and collaboration. 
 Best regards, 
Pitshou Moleka, PhD 
Author, "Transformative Leadership for Reimagining African Futures" #Africa #transformation #leadership #change #development #paradigmshift 16 40 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Coalition for a Better Future 2,160 followers 7mo Report this post Economic reconciliation is crucial for fostering #inclusive #economic #growth , and ensuring that Indigenous Peoples hold leadership positions is a key part of that. 

According to our #Scorecard report ( https://bit.ly/3vEuTCX ), representation of First Nations, Inuit, and M√©tis in management positions ‚¨á decreased to 2.4% in 2023 from 2.7% the previous year. Tabatha Bull , President and CEO of the Canadian Council for Indigenous Business emphasizes the importance of understanding why these numbers declined and suggests three ways for corporate Canada to transform their approach to #recruiting and #retaining Indigenous leadership:

üí° 1) Change the decision-making process at the board level. Consider embracing consensus decision-making and recognize that Indigenous Peoples may take time to assess the long-term impact of decisions on future generations.

üí° 2) Focus on recruiting for potential, not just experience. Relying solely on a candidate's years of experience will restrict the pool of Indigenous talent.

üí° 3) Prioritize intentional training and development. Ensure Indigenous hires receive the necessary training to prepare them for leadership roles.

üì∫ View Tabatha's full comments starting at 2:23:00 https://bit.ly/3Wv8AZI ‚úç Join the conversation. Learn about the 10 key priority areas that aim to transform Sri Lanka‚Äôs economy and drive sustainable growth for the next decade. #Vision2030LKA #ceylonchamber ‚Ä¶more 72 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Economic Research Southern Africa (ERSA) 6,104 followers 4mo Report this post As our conference on The Role of Cities as Potential Drivers of Economic Growth and Prosperity continues, we share insights from our final panel discussion between our distinguished panellists Glen Robbins , Trudi Makhaya and Harris Selod , and chaired by Saul Levin . Here, our panelists explored the role of industrial policy in enabling cities to become drivers of growth. 

Considering the array of plans and frameworks on industrial policy in South Africa over the past 3 decades, there has been little success and the spatial dynamics of inequality must be addressed. How can industrial policy be used to bring people to jobs, connect people to jobs, or bring jobs to people? What are complementary policies that are necessary to support industrial policy, encourage economic growth and the redistribution of wealth? And how different are the roles of local and national government, in driving investment?

With local development being driven significantly by entrepreneurs, national policy needs to support the local level. Harris Selod emphasised the importance of the 3 Ps (place, productivity and prosperity) and 3 Es (explain the problem; estimate the effects; and ensure all actions are aligned) in promoting development. 7 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in African Center for Economic Transformation (ACET) 20,733 followers 3mo Report this post In her recent‚ÄØinterview with Alliance magazine , Mavis Owusu-Gyamfi , President and CEO of #ACET , shares her vision for Africa's growth and its path to economic transformation: 

üîµ Intentional policymaking‚ÄØto develop value chains¬†
üîµ The‚ÄØcrucial role of philanthropy‚ÄØin building capacity¬†
üîµ The need for a robust‚ÄØknowledge ecosystem‚ÄØacross Africa

Article:¬†Optimization of a gas network fuel consumption with genetic algorithm Matthew Takerhi | Achievement researchgate.net 9 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Samantha Power Regenerative Economist, Futurist, Bioregionalist, Co-Founder & Director of the BioFi Project 2mo Edited Report this post At the start of 2025, amidst a great sense of loss, turmoil, and angst in North America and around the world, we at The BioFi Project are also feeling a profound sense of hope about the potential for the resurgent bioregional and growing regenerative economics movements this year. 

Amidst the increased dysfunction and collapse of old systems, as well as the loss of ways of life, ecosystems, structures, and perceived stability, there is space for new institutions and ways of seeing and being to emerge.

In this spirit, I am excited to share the latest 'Reality Roundtable' episode of the Great Simplification hosted by my new amazing friend Nate Hagens . It was a privilege to join the thoughtful and inspiring Daniel Christian Wahl and Isabel Carlisle to discuss why 'the future is local' and why the time for bioregioning is now. They each bring decades of wisdom from walking the walk..

I still have SO much to learn about bioregionalism, the literature that was published by the OGs in the 80s and 90s (shout out to David Haenke for sending me stuff on the reg!), what it looks like in practice, and how we grow it without allowing it to be consumed by what Nate likes to call 'the Superorganism.' And am feeling very grateful to be learning with and from incredible colleagues like Nate, Daniel, and Isabel, and you - the amazing regenerative/bioregional community. This conversation reflects some of what I've learned - but also so much of what I have left to learn and look forward to learning together!

I would love to hear what questions this conversation brings up for you and what questions on bioregionalism you might like to explore together. Are you registered for Indigenomics Design- Indigenous Wealth Dynamics?

Breakout speakers Thomas Benjoe , OneHoop and Joshua A. , Raven Indigenous Capital Partners , will discuss "Building Indigenous-Led Capital," sharing insights on economic sovereignty and Indigenous leadership. This is what Indigenomics means to them;

"Indigenomics, to me, represents a commitment to empowering Indigenous communities through financing, sustainable technology, and innovation. It involves weaving traditional Indigenous values into investment practices, emphasizing collaboration and community-focused development in the tech sector." Josh Alook

'For too long our peoples livelihood have been associated with poverty but poverty was not created by poor people. It is created by the economic and social systems that we have designed for ourselves, the institutions and concepts that make up these systems are the result of decision made by human beings. As we create them, so we can change them. Through Indigenomics we will change the institutions and concepts to see our people prosper in business and economics." Thomas Benjoe

Don't miss this chance to engage with leaders in Indigenous economic design. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 9mo Report this post Congratulations to Cora Bear, the recipient of the Indigenomics Scholarship at our recent Indigenomics Design conference! üéâ 

Hosted by the Indigenomics Institute, this scholarship honors the resilience of Indigenous people and supports Indigenous students enrolled in Business, Commerce, or Finance programs across Canada, both in the Bachelors and Masters level. This scholarship contributes to the education of Indigenous students, empowering future Indigenous leaders to take their rightful place at the economic table. Cora is currently enrolled at Saskatchewan Indian Institute of Technologies (SIIT) Miyoskamin: Innovation & Entrepreneurship Applied Certificate.

Join us in fostering Indigenous economic growth and celebrating the achievements of future leaders like Cora. For more information on how to apply or support the Indigenomics Scholarship, email events@indigenomics.com #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousExcellence #IndigenousStudents #Futureleaders 29 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Jelle Ferwerda Research Coordinator at Universiteit Twente 4mo Report this post The Africa Charter: Rebalancing the global science ecosystem

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/e6NU-DfR ontariosuniversities.ca ontariosuniversities.ca Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in ADITYA ANKARI Doctoral scholar|  Research| Plant Biologist| Immunology & Molecular Biology| tech-Lifesciences-innovation enthusiast| Concept photographer| 7mo Report this post üéì The Plight of PhD Scholars in India üáÆüá≥

Pursuing a PhD in India is not just a test of academic endurance but also a financial struggle for many scholars. The prolonged duration of PhD programs, coupled with irregular or insufficient fellowships, forces many to take up odd jobs just to make ends meet. This not only hampers their research focus but also highlights the urgent need for better financial support systems. It's time to address these challenges and ensure that our scholars can dedicate themselves fully to their research without the burden of financial insecurity. #PhDScholar #ResearchMatters #FinancialSupport #HigherEducation #India Your opinion on such state of scholars? https://lnkd.in/gAupcpEs Nationalist on Instagram: "- Google and you will find my..... - Your shop, right?? - No, my research papers on Bio-technology. #india #biotechnology #sad #but #reality" instagram.com 14 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in IRANZ Independent Research Association of New Zealand 916 followers 9mo Report this post HERA: Which matters more? Excellence or impact? HERA CEO Dr Troy Coyle (Wahine/She/Her) writes about the differences between excellent research that has impact vs impactful research that is excellent, and the potentially harmful bias in the New Zealand Science System. It's a timely article and a discussion we have been having ourselves at IRANZ as we prepared our submission for the Science System Advisory Group in May.

"The Aotearoa New Zealand research, science and innovation (RSI) system is one that purportedly values and rewards research excellence and research impact equally.

"Despite this, the current system favours an approach that focuses on excellent research that has impact vs impactful research that is excellent."

Dr Coyle writes that an alternative approach is to ensure that all proposals are assessed for both impact and excellence or that impact is the first hurdle. "Surely, all research must be high impact? Is there any point doing the most excellent research in the world if it has no impact?" #ResearchExcellence #ImpactfulResearch #ScienceDebate #ResearchImpact #NZScience #SciencePolicy #RSI #InnovationNZ #ScienceSystem #HighImpactResearch #ScienceDiscussion #ResearchMatters #ExcellenceVsImpact #HERA #iranzresearch https://lnkd.in/gaUT___z Which matters more? Excellence or impact? https://hera.org.nz 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Bioerko It√§-Suomi 163 followers 1mo Report this post Strengthening Finnish-Chilean Collaboration in Bioeconomy

As part of the Team Finland Knowledge funded project ‚ÄúFostering green transition through mobility and effective communication between Finnish and Chilean HEIs ‚Äú starting in 2022, we have been building Finnish-Chilean partnership to foster academic exchange, research collaboration, and sustainable innovation in the field of bioeconomy.

Project highlights:
‚Ä¢ Chilean academics visited Finland to explore education programs, industry practices, and research opportunities.
‚Ä¢ Finnish experts travelled to Chile, engaging in bioeconomy seminars, student exchange agreements, and circular bioeconomy development discussions.
‚Ä¢ Workshops, webinars, and vide variety of visits connected professionals, educators, and students to strengthening bioeconomy education.

GreenMOBECO project ended at the end of 2024, but collaboration is continuing in several ways, such as student and staff exchange and joint project applications.

Thank you all partners and funder! üòä #bioeconomy #circulareconomy University of Eastern Finland Karelia University of Applied Sciences Savonia University of Applied Sciences Universidad Catolica del Maule Universidad de Talca Universidad de Concepci√≥n Universidad Austral de Chile 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Center for Effective Global Action (CEGA) 16,028 followers 11mo Report this post üìäüå±Empowering research in LMICs: the impact of the DAISI Regional Scholars Program

Researchers from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) have a deep understanding of local contexts and strong relationships with policymakers, yet they contribute to only two percent of global research output. To address this, initiatives like CEGA's Global Networks program and J-PAL's Scholars Program are enhancing inclusion in and building capacity of impact evaluation by providing training, mentorship, and funding to LMIC scholars.

Launched in 2021, the Digital Agricultural Innovations and Services Initiative (DAISI), managed jointly by CEGA and J-PAL, supports research aimed at enhancing digital agricultural solutions for small-scale producers in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. The DAISI Regional Scholars Program offers PhD holders from these regions opportunities for funding and mentorship in impact evaluation methodologies.

Explore what the DAISI Regional Scholars Program has achieved in the past two years: https://buff.ly/49OENQI Celebrating the DAISI Regional Scholars Program‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäTwo-Years Strong medium.com 6 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in John Edward Clarke Business Grants Specialist | Securing Funding for Tomorrow's Innovators 9mo Report this post The UKRI Ayrton challenge programme full stage (invite only) 

Apply for funding for interdisciplinary, challenge-led research projects enabling the transition to low carbon energy in developing countries.

UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) will fund around 10 projects between ¬£2 to ¬£3 million for up to three years. 80% of the full economic costs (FEC) will be available for the UK component of each project. Partners in countries on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Development Assistance Committee (DAC) list will be funded at 100% of FEC.

First is the absence of opportunity we have experienced as Indigenous peoples through the reserve systems through removal of the ability to access numerous opportunities. The second source of poverty is the absence of proximity to our teachings." Carol Anne Hilton, CEO, Indigenomics Institute

Carol Anne Hilton's powerful words at our recent Indigenomics Design conference highlight the critical need to address these roots of poverty and underscored the importance of economic reconciliation and cultural revitalization for Indigenous communities.

Let‚Äôs talk in the comments! #GeographyTutor #GeographyTuition Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in MA Sustainable Development Practice TERI SAS 770 followers 5mo Report this post International Day for the Eradication of Poverty: A Global Call to Action

On October 17th, the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty brings attention to the ongoing global struggle against poverty and calls for collective action. This year‚Äôs theme, ‚ÄúEnding Social and Institutional Maltreatment,‚Äù urges us to address not only economic hardship but also the social and institutional barriers that perpetuate poverty.

Since its recognition by the United Nations in 1992, this day has amplified the voices of those affected by poverty to ensure fair access to education, employment, and essential services, which are vital for building more inclusive societies.

However, fight against poverty is not limited to lack of basic needs anymore. It is about the underlying absence of opportunities, freedom of choice and participation in decision making. Achieving SDG 1 refers to the idea of equal and equitable access to resources that envisions a future where all communities have a fair chance to grow and succeed.

By working together, we can create a society where every individual has the opportunity to thrive. As development practitioners, it is essential to take shared responsibility, to bring affirmative changes for a better future. The fight against poverty is far from over. The 2024 UN SDG Report highlights the critical need for action to close the gaps in social protection and climate resilience. 

With millions still facing extreme poverty, especially in vulnerable regions, the path forward demands focused efforts to support those most affected.

 IT Support Expert | Data Enthusiast| Certified Educator | SDGs Promoter | Co-founder Codeville Girls | God's Chosen 5mo Report this post The #International #Day for the #Eradication of #Poverty is observed annually on October 17.

 Established by the United Nations in 1992, it commemorates a 1987 gathering in #Paris where over 100,000 people honored victims of poverty. The day aims to promote dialogue between those living in poverty and society, emphasizing that poverty is a violation of #humanrights . 

Activities include raising awareness, supporting anti-poverty organizations, and advocating for #policy changes to combat #poverty , #violence and #hunger globally


In December 1995, the United Nations General #Assembly proclaimed the First United Nations Decade for the Eradication of Poverty (1997‚Äì2006), following the #Copenhagen Social Summit. UNESCO 's involvement in the fight against poverty on October 17 emphasizes the importance of #education , #science , and #cultural #initiatives as tools for #empowerment . 

By promoting #capacity building, UNESCO supports individuals in overcoming poverty through #skills #development and #creative #economies , which foster employment and dignity. The organization aligns its efforts with the #2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, particularly Goal 1, which aims to end #poverty in all forms.

 UNESCO also facilitates dialogue between impoverished #communities and #society , ensuring their voices are heard in the #global conversation on poverty eradication 3 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Global Alliance Against Hunger and Poverty 1,849 followers 4mo Report this post Today, at the #2030Sprints during #G20Social , countries, organisations, and development banks announced the most robust collective effort to date to eradicate hunger and reduce poverty through public policies. These announcements highlight early actions aligned with the forthcoming launch of the Global Alliance Against Hunger and Poverty, set to take place at the G20 Leaders‚Äô Summit in Rio.

Minister Wellington Dias (MDS/Brazil) underscored the critical importance of integrating socioeconomic initiatives to drive regional economic growth. #GlobalAlliance2024 #EndHunger &Poverty #EndHunger #EndPoverty #SDGs #SDG1 #SDG2 #g20social #nohunger &poverty G20 Brasil 2024 43 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Aisulu Mailybayeva Operations Analyst at The World Bank 3mo Report this post The World Bank Group has set a clear mission: ending poverty and boosting shared prosperity on a livable planet.¬†This report offers the first post-pandemic assessment of global progress toward these interlinked goals, and explores potential pathways out of today's polycrisis - an environment where multiple and interconnected challenges are impacting the world simultaneously.¬†The report's messages are presented around progress in terms of the goals, pathways to move forward, and priorities depending on where countries stand on the interlinked goals. #EndPoverty The World Bank 2,408,060 followers 4mo Progress on #poverty reduction has stalled. Almost 700 million people globally still live in extreme poverty ‚Äì on less than $2.15 a day. What will it take to get back on track to #EndPoverty ? (2008) identified a significant negative correlation between nitrogen fertilizer use and bird species richness. Birds in agricultural landscapes are more likely to decline due to cascading ecological impacts of high fertilizer use, such as reduced plant and insect diversity and eutrophication of aquatic habitats. However, increasing the area of semi-natural habitats (e.g., hedgerows and uncultivated margins) in agricultural landscapes can mitigate these negative effects by providing alternative resources and habitats for birds.

First created by the Second Committee of the UN General Assembly in¬†1993, IDB is a celebration of biological diversity‚Äîa day to educate and bring awareness to biodiversity issues worldwide.

Biodiversity¬†encompasses all the different living things found in an area, including animals, insects, fungi, plant life, and microorganisms. This complex mix of life is a delicate balance, as every organism relies on others to survive. 

Great Ecology engages with practices of strengthening biodiversity through our projects. We lead the way in creative solutions for ecological problems, working with clients to preserve biological diversity in the face of complex environmental issues.

Today, on #WorldElephantDay , we recognize the vital roles that large herbivores like elephants, as well as predators and pollinators, play in maintaining healthy ecosystems. Unfortunately, all of these species face serious threats whenever humans introduce farmed animals, disrupting the natural balance and endangering biodiversity.

This annual conference serves to amplify the leadership, experiences and voices of Indigenous women in business who are advancing the Indigenous economy through tools such as procurement, investment, equity ownership, trusts, trade, entrepreneurship, finance and technology. 

The agenda is crafted with passion and purpose, focusing on GROWTH, CAREER, SKILLS and INSIGHT DEVELOPMENT to support evolving leadership.

Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1mo Edited Report this post The Indigenous economy is rising‚Äîand we‚Äôre inviting dynamic voices to take the stage at Indigenomics IMPACT!  join the conversation as a speaker at this transformative gathering of Indigenous businesses, corporate leaders, investors, and Indigenous leaders who are advancing economic reconciliation, Indigenous business growth, and innovative economic partnerships.

Why Speak at Indigenomics IMPACT?
-Share your success story in driving Indigenous economic inclusion.
-Connect with leaders from Indigenous businesses, corporations, governments, and investors.
-Inspire action and collaboration to activate the full potential of the Indigenous economy.

This is more than an event‚Äîit‚Äôs a call to action for Indigenous economic empowerment and inclusion. It's time to showcase your leadership and insights at a conference that is activating the full potential of the Indigenous economy.

üîó Apply now: https://lnkd.in/eCHP8nVs #IndigenomicsIMPACT #IndigenousEconomy #EconomicReconciliation #IndigenousBusiness #FutureofIndigenomics 84 8 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Global Pharma Solutions 1,629 followers 8mo Report this post Our Founder and Principal, Margaret Jenkins attended a Women on Life Sciences Boards Lunch recently and was inspired by the discussion around the number of women represented on boards in Australia and the progress that is be made in this space.
¬†
Key take away thoughts to consider were:
- Diversity on boards in terms of both gender and skillset is important.
- Skills in governance as well as financial literacy are essential to be present on boards. In addition, skills in life sciences provide an important balance.
- The discussion around prior board experience vs skillset, provided some food for thought on whether prior board experience is always needed, if the skillset is a good fit.
- ‚ÄúBoard observer‚Äù opportunities could help aspiring board members gain the boardroom experience needed to be considered for future positions
¬†
GPS would like to thank Rosanne Hyland COO, Ausbiotech, the Victorian state branch committee AusBiotech , Michelle Burke (for the valuable analyses of 700 boards in Australia) and Grant Thornton (US) who kindly hosted the lunch. However, those companies continue to grow their share of capital raised. https://lnkd.in/giZGy6Yg According to a report by the McKinsey Institute and the World Economic Forum,¬†investing in women's health can boost the global economy by $1 trillion annually by 2040‚Äîa 1.7 percent increase in the average per capita GDP generated by women.
While healthcare companies have received 25% of the overall funding market over the last few years, women's health represented 2% of the $41.2 billion in funding they received in 2023, explained Jennifer Radin, MPH, MBA, principal of Deloitte Consulting LLP, during Asembia's AXS24 Summit in Las Vegas. #invivosciences #Titan 100 CEO
# Heart Failure #precision medicine #Technology #Innovation Sharron Cox CEO |Executive Search | Bioscience | Nonprofit | Host "She Leads Biotech" the podcast. | 40+ year veteran of the recruitment industry 4mo Female Leadership for True Innovation! 

My guest tomorrow on She Leads Biotech is President & CEO of Invivo Biosciences , Ayla Annac . whose journey¬†takes us from her roots in Turkey to her pioneering work in the biotech space, where she's making strides in heart disease treatment.

Ayla is a passionate advocate for increasing female representation at all levels in biotech. 

She believes that diversity in leadership, especially from women, brings essential perspectives and drives collaboration over competition. 

Her commitment to mentorship and supporting other women in science is a testament to her belief in lifting others as she climbs. 9 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Kintiga 6,845 followers 3mo Report this post Last night, we had the privilege of attending BioIndustry Association (BIA) 's Women in Biotech event in London, with Marianne Lambertson and Karina Tatagiba Gon√ßalves representing the MAP Group. The event highlighted the challenges faced by female founders and the ongoing barriers for women in leadership roles within the life sciences sector.
¬†
We were honoured to participate and contribute to the conversation about driving positive change in the industry. One CEO and founder shared a striking experience: of the 100+ venture capital firms she approached, over 60% suggested appointing a male CEO to improve her chances of success.
¬†
Another key takeaway was that only about one-third of grant funding in the UK is allocated to female-founded organisations. The panel discussion explored actionable steps we can take now and in the future to support women-led initiatives.
¬†
Thank you to BIA for hosting such an inspiring event‚Äîwe look forward to connecting with colleagues at future opportunities. #WomenInBiotech #BIA #LifeSciences #WomenInLeadership 129 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Observer Research Foundation 91,513 followers 6mo Report this post Observer Research Foundation and Reliance Foundation , in collaboration with United Nations in India , are delighted to launch the report "The Next Frontier: Charting the Contours of the Post-2030 Development Agenda"!

This volume explores the strategies, innovations, and leadership required to forge a new global development agenda beyond 2030. It not only underlines the challenges that confront us but illuminates the pathways that can lead to a more resilient, inclusive, and sustainable world. 

This publication comprises twenty-seven essays authored by a range of authors from the development, philanthropy, and think tank sectors, as well as policymakers and other thought leaders, carrying voices from both the Global North and the Global South.

Read the full report hereüëâ https://or-f.org/30862 ‚Ä¶more 53 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Alexis Tennent Innovative Leader and Design & Foresight Strategist 11mo Edited Report this post Participants in a workshop I ran this week asked if there are any free public foresight events coming up. The answer is yes! I figured I would share here too for those who are interested in foresight but perhaps not yet as connected to the wonderful foresight community. 

There are two online events coming up in early May that I have my eye on:

May 1, 2024, 9am EST: Enhancing Women's Leadership In and Through Foresight by Global Foresight Advisory Council (GFAC) This should be a great panel discussion! 
Moderator: Thays Prado
Panelists: Zan Chandler, B√°rbara Ferrer Lanz, and Kelsey Volkmann.
Free registration here: https://lnkd.in/g-3HcsCN May 7-9, 2024: Policy Horizons Canada - Horizons de politiques Canada (the federal government's strategic foresight department) Futures Week
29 speakers over 3 days!
Anyone can register and attend: https://lnkd.in/gSBCkxDM For those who are new to or just starting to learn about foresight: You don't need to be a foresight practitioner to attend these events. If you need that little confidence boost, remind yourself that no one is an expert about the future, but everyone (including you) has expertise that is important to the future. You are not just welcome, you are vital. 

See you there! #foresight #futuresthinking GFAC Live! May 2024 https://my.tfsx.com 33 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Kourtney Pompi Executive Leader | Democracy, Good Governance, Civic Engagement and Human Rights | Expert in Team and Coalition Building | Systems Thinker and Problem Solver 11mo Report this post Sharing the latest Counterpart white paper developed by our growing #WomensEmpowerment team. Add it to your weekly reading list! We want to thank the co-sponsors of the March 5 event that helped fuel the paper, including EnCompass LLC , Chemonics International , and Saudat Salami . Thank you as well to the amazing speakers - Thilma Komaling , Rachel Vogelstein , Corinne Hart, Isabel Beltr√°n , Anjani Harjeven , Camille Richardson , and Beatriz Moreno Lopez - who helped us to cultivate the paper's recommendations. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomics‚Äô Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 10mo Report this post The expression of Indigenous value, of value creation and the distribution of wealth is expressed through ceremony and relationships within Indigenous reality. 

For thousands of years, wealth has been expressed through giving, the transaction, the distribution through ceremony and based upon the quality of recognition of relationship and connection to each other, to our environment, and to resources with respect for life at the heart of both the economy and ceremony. 

This is Indigenomics.

This important session invited dialogue on how Indigenous trusts and investment strategies have evolved significantly over the last 50 years.
