B.C. plans to 'reconcile' by giving First Nations veto on land use: op-ed fraserinstitute.org 17 7 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Steven Wilson Managing Partner Qooluun Ventures, Inc. 12mo Report this comment In 1973 the Supreme Court of Canada in the Calder reasons for judgment established that aboriginal title exists and can be infringed if justified, modified or extinguished only by to federal crown, to the federal crown, and only if backed by competent legislation and then only when specific legislation is established.

All crown lands have not been subject to any competent or specific legislation modifying or extinguishing our lands and resources. That is the basis for unceded lands and resource! Like Reply 2¬†Reactions 3¬†Reactions Ron Johnston Director - Office for Aboriginal Peoples, Simon Fraser University ( Retired ) 12mo Report this comment More right wing dogma that is adamant to maintain the colonial status quo from days gone by, which refuses to recognize and honour Indigenous rights and title that has always been here on the unceeded lands that in more recent time are now called Canada and British Columbia respectively. Not only does it harm the Indigenous individual being exploited, used, and appropriated solely for their Indigenous identity but it also puts projects at great risk. When major projects are at great risk, the investments made with intentions to reach communities are not realized, and the outcomes or impacts are not achieved. This means exacerbated socioeconomic inequities of Indigenous communities. This behaviour dictates how [or if] these project investments have true impact on the Canadian economy. There's significant negative economic impact of tokenism, appropriation, and exploitation of Indigenous Identity- to the country. It's not just an 'Indigenous problem'. 

Want to begin to understand the topic more? Start with Len Pierre ‚Äôs FREE webinar! There are current studies examining this behaviour and its technical implications. My idea of a 21st-century magazine consists of three pillars:

1. The Magazine itself, featuring original thoughts on the most interesting stories of our time.

2. Programs that study particular topics over a long period to produce valuable insights.

3. Live Events that engage people directly and invite them to "join the discussion."

So whether you want to read a definitive Chronicle of human civilization, explore the 24 World Districts that make up around 95% of our population, or discover forgotten cinematic masterpieces curated by a New Yorker playwright, SocietyReview.org will be your first address. We hope your studies in Innovation & Entrepreneurship continue to empower you to be the best that you can be! #Indigenomics #Saskatoon 13 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Eternity Biotech, Inc. 19 followers 10mo Report this post As we work to unveil the future of aging, we are thrilled to announce that we've been selected for the Yale Innovation Summit 2024 Virtual Showcase! 

Happening May 29th - 30th at the Yale University campus, we're excited to connect with leading investors, industry innovators, and fellow biotech pioneers at this premier event. Join us as we explore the future of longevity and share our mission to revolutionize the human experience.

Interested in learning more about Eternity Biotech? Reach out to our team to schedule a meeting at the summit!

In the meantime, let us know in the comments below what you're most looking forward to - see you there! #EternityBiotech #longevity #biotech #antiaging #YaleInnovationSummit #YaleInnovation24 #YaleVentures #innovation #entrepreneurship Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in GeneOnline 5,681 followers 7mo Report this post Despite significant global shifts over the past 45 years, the leading biotech regions have remained steady. A recent study by European academics analyzed growth from 1978 to 2015 and found that the San Francisco Bay Area, Massachusetts, and Japan‚Äôs Southern Kanto region are still the top three clusters. üî¨


Early investment, scientific excellence, strong networks, and diverse business ecosystems contributed to their success. The study highlights that thriving biotech clusters depend on vibrant science bases and broad entrepreneurial support. üß¨


Read more at üëâüèª https://t.ly/dWG7k #Biotech #Innovation #ScienceAndBusiness #Entrepreneurship #BiotechClusters #Research #GlobalGrowth #Healthcare 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in ICABB JIIT ICABB 2025 (8th edition) focuses on "Innovations in Biomedicine, Biotechnology & Computational Biology." It brings together experts to share breakthroughs via lectures, oral, and poster sessions across 5 major themes. 2mo Report this post "Join us for the ICABB 2025 Industry Interaction and Panel Discussion on 31st January 2025, a premier platform bringing together industry leaders, academic experts, and aspiring professionals to exchange knowledge and foster collaboration in the field of biotechnology and applied sciences.
This session will focus on critical themes, including:
üî¨ Development of industry-specific skills tailored to the evolving scientific landscape.
üìö Embracing lifelong learning as a cornerstone for sustained professional growth.
üí° Nurturing innovative thinking to address global scientific challenges.
üöÄ Exploring entrepreneurial opportunities in cutting-edge domains.
This is an excellent opportunity to engage in meaningful dialogue, share insights, and gain actionable perspectives for advancing in the biotechnology and innovation ecosystem.
üìÖ Session Date: 31st January 2025
üåê Learn more at: https://www.icabb25.com #ICABB2025 #ScientificInnovation #Biotechnology #Entrepreneurship #LifelongLearning #ResearchAndDevelopment " 18 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Nucleate Baltimore | DC 63 followers 4mo Edited Report this post Excited to announce the launch of the Nucleate Baltimore | DC Chapter! 

We're here to empower the next generation of biotech entrepreneurs by providing open-access resources, sparking intellectual communities, and fostering collaboration across ecosystems. Our mission is to make biotech education more accessible and to support budding innovators in our region.
Whether you're a scientist, an aspiring entrepreneur, or just passionate about the future of biotechnology, we'd love for you to be part of our journey.

Follow us as we build a thriving biotech community in Baltimore | DC! üå±
Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gD7GFyB9 #Nucleate #Biotech #BaltimoreDC #Entrepreneurship #Innovation 26 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in biomindz 3,218 followers 3mo Report this post üë©üî¨ ùóòùó´ùóúùó¶ùóß-ùó™ùóºùó∫ùó≤ùóª: ùóòùó∫ùóΩùóºùòÑùó≤ùóøùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóôùó≤ùó∫ùóÆùóπùó≤ ùóôùóºùòÇùóªùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄ
Are you ready to turn your vision into reality in the #LifeSciences or #Biotechnology sector? 

The ùóòùó´ùóúùó¶ùóß-ùó™ùóºùó∫ùó≤ùóª program is here to support female founders on their journey to launching a start-up.ü§ù

With tailored advisory services, coaching & mentoring programs, valuable networking opportunities and financial support, this initiative is designed to help you succeed. üöÄ 

The Johannes Gutenberg-Universit√§t Mainz and the Hochschule Mainz - University of Applied Sciences are joining forces to submit an application for this program by the Bundesministerium f√ºr Wirtschaft und Klimaschutz .

Since ùóóùó≤ùó∞ùó≤ùó∫ùóØùó≤ùóø ùüµ you can apply! Details regarding eligibility and the application form will be available on the Startup Center‚Äôs website.

üå± Why #Mainz ?
Mainz and Rhineland-Palatinate are a hub of innovation for #LifeSciences and #Biotechnology . With Initiatives like ùóòùó´ùóúùó¶ùóß-ùó™ùóºùó∫ùó≤ùóª and a strong network of research institutions, businesses, and entrepreneurial support, Mainz is the perfect place to bring your ideas to life! #MainzThePlaceToBiotech üëâ Learn more about it: See link below. #EXISTWomen #StartupSupport #WomenInScience #Innovation #Entrepreneurship 23 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Abbio XR, Inc. 79 followers 2mo Edited Report this post We‚Äôre thrilled to announce that Abbio XR is competing in the University of Notre Dame McCloskey¬†New¬†Venture¬†Competition, an incredible opportunity that fosters innovation and entrepreneurship. üéâ

At Abbio XR, our mission is to revolutionize drug delivery with cutting-edge hydrogel technology, enabling extended-release solutions like our GLP-1 agonist to improve patient care and transform therapeutic outcomes. Participating in the McCloskey Competition is an exciting opportunity to share our vision with a diverse community of innovators and thought leaders who are driving impactful change across industries.

This competition offers much more than the chance to pitch our ideas. It‚Äôs about refining our strategy, gaining invaluable feedback, and collaborating with Notre Dame‚Äôs extensive network of mentors, advisors, and investors. Additionally, we have partnered with two exceptional Notre Dame undergraduate students from the Notre Dame Biotech Club , Andrew Coath & Alex Moeller . These two students are responsible for conducting market research, building slide decks, and ultimately championing Abbio by participating in recorded and live pitches.

Follow along as we take this important step forward, building on Abbio XR‚Äôs vision to make healthcare more effective, accessible, and patient-centered. Together, we can "Innovate Like A Champion Today!" #McCloskeyVentureCompetition #BiotechInnovation #NotreDame #Entrepreneurship #HealthcareTransformation #GLP1s #BiotechStartup 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Leslie Dan Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Toronto 8,341 followers 3mo Report this post Ontario is driving global life sciences innovation, but unlocking its full potential requires bold investments in academic research, entrepreneurship, and early-stage start-ups. At the 2024 Ontario Economic Summit, Dr. Christine Allen emphasized the need to support homegrown innovation and talent to keep Ontario at the forefront.

Read more about the future of our innovation ecosystem: https://ow.ly/ipRp50Uiebu #ImPharmacy | #LifeSciences | #Innovation | #OES2024 Catalyzing Ontario‚Äôs bioeconomy through academic research and innovation pharmacy.utoronto.ca 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Boehringer Ingelheim 1,940,248 followers 2mo Report this post Great discoveries often require special nurturing and optimal environments in order to thrive and turn into a breakthrough for patients.¬†That's why we support the innovation power from young life-science companies and bio-entrepreneurs.
Do you want to advance your innovation? Apply for the Heidelberg Innovation Prize and gain access to lab space and equipment at the world-class incubator at BioLabs.
¬†
Register by February 7th: https://lnkd.in/eB_9Nc2B #LifeSciences #Innovation #Entrepreneurship 100 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in KANISHKA SAIN Research Enthusiast| MSc Biotechnology Student at TERI School of Advanced Studies| Alumni of University of Delhi |Pursued BSc Life Sciences from Dyal Singh College| Exploring Biotechnology Applications in Life Sciences| 2mo Report this post I'm Thrilled to Share! üéâ I've recently completed an Online Workshop on Entrepreneurship in Biotechnology, organized by Biosrishti This comprehensive program has equipped me with the essential knowledge and skills required to succeed in the biotech industry. üöÄ

Key Takeaways:
‚ú® Biotech innovation and commercialization
‚ú® Business plan development and pitching
‚ú® Funding opportunities and strategies
‚ú® Regulatory frameworks and compliance

I'm grateful for the support of the Department of Biotechnology , Government of India, which has been instrumental in promoting biotech innovation and entrepreneurship in the country.

Description: Nov 4, 2023  ¬∑  In a few weeks I'll be on a panel at the Indigenomics Bay Street conference in Toronto. I really look forward to this rewarding and engaging¬†...
Extracted_Text:
In a few weeks I‚Äôll be on a panel at the Indigenomics Bay Street‚Ä¶ | Derrick Neeposh Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Derrick Neeposh‚Äôs Post Derrick Neeposh Chairman/President - Board of Compensation/CREECO 1y Report this post In a few weeks I‚Äôll be on a panel at the Indigenomics Bay Street conference in Toronto. I really look forward to this rewarding and engaging experience. Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y The Road to a $100 Billion Indigenous Economy! This ambitious vision is within our reach, but it requires the collective strength and wisdom of Indigenous business leaders from coast to coast.

Join us for a game-changing session led by distinguished visionaries: Chana Martineau BA, ICD.D , CEO, Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , Derrick Neeposh , CREECO, Ted Bauer , Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , and Crystal Chief   B.A., M. Ed. , Haisla Nation Council. They will guide us through the strategic pathways to achieve this monumental goal.  In this exclusive discussion, we will delve into:

-The blueprint for success: Insights and strategies to help Indigenous businesses strategically navigate towards a $100 billion economy.
-Building bridges: Discover what's needed from corporate partners and governments to create an enabling environment for Indigenous economic empowerment.
-Expert perspectives: Gain invaluable knowledge from two leaders who have blazed trails in Indigenous entrepreneurship and economic development.

But hurry, time is of the essence! Only 11 days left to register and be part of this historic dialogue that will shape the future of Indigenous economic empowerment.
Secure your spot now, and let's embark on this transformational journey together.  Don't miss out on your chance to be a part of this pivotal moment in history.

Title: Jen Newsted's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Jun 9, 2023  ¬∑  #Reconciliation #IndigenousHistoryMonth #Indigenomics ¬∑ View organization page for Indigenomics, graphic ¬∑ Indigenomics. 4,665 followers. 1y¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#reconciliation #indigenoushistorymonth #indigenomics | Jen Newsted Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Jen Newsted‚Äôs Post Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 1y Report this post I had a conversation with a white woman earlier this year about reconciliation and they had shared that if they can't get it right their organization wasn't going to go anywhere near it.

This perspective is one that many individuals and businesses have across the country, this isn't new news.

It is a problematic perspective because it continues to uphold racism and systems of oppression. 

We are each, individually, and collectively, responsible to be righting relations and actively responding to Truth and Reconciliation Call to Action 92. 

It is phenomenally straightforward what we are meant to do, as example:
Listen to Indigenous voices.
Learn from Indigenous voices.
Invest in Indigenous voices.
Support Indigenous voices.
Be led by Indigenous voices.
Believe Indigenous voices.

When I think about folks who say they don't want to get it wrong so they aren't going to do anything, I wonder why they are so comfortable to share their very obvious tells that they haven't taken any of the above straightforward steps, that they aren't interested in taking a look within, and they have no concern about the harms they continue to uphold.

If you just don't know where to start, here is a suggestion, get in the room where Indigenous folks are leading and sharing. 

There is an incredible opportunity in Toronto this November and every sector I have been part of advertising, healthcare, tech, non-profit, tv and film, telecommunications absolutely have no reason to not be in this room. 

Let's get in this room and start shifting our individual and collective accountability into impactful actions that right relations and ensure prosperity for those whose lands we keep saying we live, work and play on.

Let's show up beyond our continued copy and paste acknowledgements of being on stolen land and step into dismantling the barriers we know exist and that we are benefitting from. #Reconciliation #IndigenousHistoryMonth #Indigenomics Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Edited The Indigenomics Institute welcomes Raylene Whitford and Frank Busch as conference emcees for Indigenomics on BAY STREET- the 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy conference, taking place November 21 - 23, 2023 in the City of Toronto !

Indigenomics on BAY STREET will be the largest Indigenous economy focused coming together of leadership across the corporate / private sector, governments and Indigenous business to bring focus, meaning and visibility to the emerging 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy and situating that within growing Indigenous economic influence!

Conference delegates joining from outside of Toronto can enjoy the Indigenomics conference rate for their stay at The Westin Harbour Castle, Toronto !

Early bird registration ends June 30, register today to save! https://lnkd.in/evegFEqn #Indigenomics #TorontoEvents #EconomicDevelopment #EconomicReconciliation #CANECON #EconomicGrowth 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 2,136 followers 656 Posts 1 Article View Profile Follow More from this author An invitation: support & celebrate empowerment of women in Vancouver. I start and grow organizations, create conversations and channel ideas that each serve a more just, joyful and connected world. 9mo Report this post A mindset that restores our relationship to earth, and each other, as a deep ‚Äúamongness‚Äù is more than a triple bottom line. It‚Äôs a way of #livingfromoneness .

We‚Äôre all in this earthship together - you do everything right and your country or economy or the climate goes sideways, there aren‚Äôt exemptions. Maybe you protect your people in the short run, but anything beyond crisis response we‚Äôre all together now, and that calls for new economies and governance models. 

A regenerative mindset is beyond sustainable- it‚Äôs deeply for life. Bridget McKenzie 9mo I've updated my new paper with this graphic. 
This paper aims to reframe and state the case for the roles of Culture in response to the Earth crisis, to generate new areas for investment and evidence-gathering. 

I've defined some key terms, set out how the Earth crisis is a ‚Äòculture crisis‚Äô, and identified the barriers to an effective Cultural response.

I then suggest some new thematic areas of Cultural practice. 

How can Culture be an agent for a shift to a Regenerative culture and respond to the emergency in ways that aim for Transformative Adaptation and Resilience?

WATCH; Anthony Viljoen , CEO, explain how the new ownership structure will accelerate development of its key assets in Namibia. 

Watch ‚ñ∂Ô∏è https://lnkd.in/e3gURgDS Andrada Mining Limited‚ÄØ(AIM: ATM, OTCQB: ATMTF), the technology-metals producer with mining and exploration assets in Namibia,‚ÄØis seeking to increase the ownership of its main operating subsidiary (‚ÄúUTMC‚Äù) from 85% to 100%, through the acquisition of the 15% interest currently held by the Small Miners of Uis ("SMU"). 

Total consideration is to be satisfied through the issue of ¬£0.5m of ordinary shares in Andrada, ¬£0.78m in cash over 240 monthly instalments and the transfer of the Company‚Äôs 85% interest in license ML129, which is now non-core to Andrada, but regarded as a valuable opportunity for SMU to drive economic growth across the Erongo region in Namibia.  

Following completion of this transaction, Andrada will own 100% of UTMC, ensuring fair economic exposure to the development of the licenses in Namibia for all parties, further streamline operations for accelerated value creation and enable UTMC to apply for specific project financing solutions. 

Anthony Viljoen, Chief Executive Officer of Andrada‚ÄØexplains: 
- Why the restructuring process took so long 
- How the restructuring will help attract strategic partners to Andrada‚Äôs lithium assets 
- Why the lithium assets may soon‚ÄØaccount for approximately 70% of the company‚Äôs overall revenues 
‚ÄØ- How Andrada has become a‚ÄØtriple asset developer, producer and cashflow generator 
- Why the company‚Äôs tin assets are so valuable and why the  price rally in the metal will continue 
- The multiple revenue streams materialising from Andrada‚Äôs one mining operation strategy‚ÄØ 

Viljoen commented; ‚ÄúWe don't see this as a departure of our relationship with the SMU. In fact, if anything, it's strengthened our ties with them. It's given the SMU a renewed focus in terms of assisting us with our corporate social responsibilities and ensuring that our success on UIS is carried over to our other assets because a key part of this restructure is making sure that our entire portfolio realizes value.‚Äù‚ÄØ 

Reasons to add‚ÄØATM‚ÄØto your watchlist: 
- Andrada is a multi-asset, multi-commodity, multi-decade opportunity on multiple assets 
- Globally significant and JORC-compliant mineral resource estimate of 138 million tonnes 
- Open-pit mining, tin oxide coarse crushing, only being 230km from a port means low production costs and competitive logistics prices 
- Resource contains high purity lithium constituting of 0,73% at 1,45 million tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent 
- Andrada‚Äôs cash flow allows the company to develop its assets organically 
- The partnership with the‚ÄØBank of‚ÄØWindhoek‚ÄØmeans the company doesn‚Äôt have to solely rely on dilutive equity funding for development capital berenberg Tavistock Hannam & Partners #ATM #Andrada #Mining #Tin #Lithium #Namibia ‚Ä¶more Andrada Mining acquisition elevates the miner to‚ÄØemerging mid-tier status https://www.youtube.com/ 18 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SearchSpace AI 243 followers 7mo Report this post Gold Fields is set to acquire Osisko Mining in a massive $2.16 billion all-cash dealüí∞

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Justin Holness‚Äô Post Justin Holness Artist/Entrepreneur/Wealth Coach 1y Report this post It is always such an honour to collaborate with Indigenomics Institute and The Frog Radio to curate a musical experience with the inspiration of a $100 Billion Indigenous Economy!!! #lightitup #indigenomics Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Ready to Light it up? Only 13 Days Left to Register for the Indigenomics on Bay Street Conference, and we've got the ultimate musical treat for you!‚ÄØ 
 
Get ready to groove to the rhythm of Indigenomics like never before with the exclusive "Indigenomics Playlist", carefully curated by the incredible duo Denise Halfyard of The Frog Radio and Justin Holness of Tr1be Music. https://lnkd.in/gyDuKdWe As we approach the conference, let the music set the stage for what's to come ‚Äì a celebration of Indigenous success, knowledge, and collaboration. It's more than just a soundtrack; it's the heartbeat of a movement.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Kelsey Debets‚Äô Post Kelsey Debets Regional Director, Procurement Assistance Canada - Western Region at Public Services and Procurement Canada 1y Report this post Blessed to be a part of #Indigenomics SHE. Modern Inidgenous Economic Design ü§© Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y What we set out to do with Indigenomics SHE was to amplify the voices of what are our experiences as Indigenous women in business- to create a space of a strengths based narrative of really how are we killing it ‚Äì there‚Äôs difficulties, there‚Äôs challenges, there's so much that we‚Äôve overcome, and¬†to come together to support each other, to build a network and be able to advance this perspective. What we are doing is essential. Essential for our families. Essential for our communities. Essential for our futures. ‚Äú Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D , opening remarks Indigenomics SHE. ¬†
¬†
Thank you to Elder Billie Schibler for opening our day in a good way, and to all the incredible leaders who shared their stories, knowledge and wisdom with us yesterday. Title: Audra Young's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Feb 29, 2024  ¬∑  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #10towatch #treaty4territory #mnsregion3 #cityofregina | Audra Young Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Audra Young‚Äôs Post Audra Young Director Indigenous Relations and Community Development City of Regina 1y Report this post Thank you Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D for this acknowledgement. The City of Regina is early on the pathway of reconciliation, we have much work to do. We are honored to have been entrusted to do this work with the guidance and direction of the Indigneous Procurement Advisory Committee. #INDIGENOMICS #10TOWATCH #Treaty4Territory #MNSRegion3 #CityofRegina Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y ‚ÄúRegina‚Äôs Indigenous Procurement Policy is a commitment to creating a thriving environment where Indigenous entrepreneurship can flourish,‚Äù shares Audra Young , Director of Indigenous Relations.

Shining a spotlight on The City of Regina , who is recognized as a distinguished recipient on the 2023 Indigenomics #10TOWATCH List and commended for their efforts to build economic reconciliation, inclusion and design business relationships to support the growth of the Indigenous economy, at the Indigenomics BAY STREET Conference.

The City of Regina is demonstrating its commitment to reconciliation through their Indigenous Procurement Policy. (IPP) 

The municipality has outlined a minimum goal of achieving 20 percent engagement for Indigenous procurement. This is a major step along the journey to economic reconciliation as a municipality and a clear step forward for economic reconciliation. 

This is Indigenomics in ACTION! Title: Angela DeMontigny on LinkedIn
Description: Mar 31, 2022  ¬∑  #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics ... #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics‚Ä¶ | Angela DeMontigny Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Angela DeMontigny‚Äôs Post Angela DeMontigny Designer, Artist, Visionary, Pioneer, Entrepreneur, Mentor ~ Indigenous Fashion, Wellness & Public Art 2y Report this post Thank you Jen Newsted for amplifying and supporting Indigenous women entrepreneurs! #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics #decolonizedbusiness #economicinclusion #indigenouswellness #indigenousbusiness Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 2y Economic reconciliation was the topic that M√©tis entrepreneur Vanessa Lesperance, MA, GDBA founder of Mindful Managers, a space that is devoted to workplace spirituality, increasing employee well-being and decolonizing business, shared about in a recent learning circle.

Vanessa is also the lead for the Lift Circle at Indigenous Lift Collective who are co-creating the conditions for Indigenous women entrepreneurs to thrive.

In our learning circle Vanessa offered two definitions of economic reconciliation:

‚ÄúEconomic reconciliation is a form of reconciliation in action. It is a commitment by all stakeholders involved to create meaningful paths of self-determination, relationships and equitable partnerships.‚Äù - Chief Leanne Joe

‚ÄúEconomic reconciliation is the space between the lived realities of Indigenous Peoples, the need to build understanding of the important Indigenous relationship, and the requirement for progressive actions for economic inclusion.‚Äù - Carol Anne Hilton

Last week Rexall Pharmacy Group ULC launched an Indigenous Wellness end aisle pilot in 10 locations across the country.¬†

Three brands owned and led by Mohawk, Cree and M√©tis¬†women entrepreneurs. Here is what they had to say about this pilot:

"This opportunity is Reconciliation in action. When you lift up female-led, Indigenous brands, you lift the entire Indigenous community.‚Äù April Mitchell-Boudreau founder Lofttan.

This wonderful partnership and unprecedented pilot program to support and promote Indigenous, women-owned businesses and brands is what the Indigenous community and this country needs. Angela DeMontigny founder Lodge Soy Candles.

‚ÄúAs a descendent of a residential school survivor, I am appreciative that Rexall is honouring the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada‚Äôs Calls to Action. kinan√¢skomitin (thank you, I am grateful to you).‚Äù Carrie Armstrong founder Mother Earth Essentials.

As individuals and as businesses we can each activate our economic reconciliation. Hire Indigenous leaders like Vanessa for learning circles. Purchase products from Indigenous owned businesses like Lofttan, Lodge Soy Candles, Mother Earth Essentials. Ask the businesses you support to start carrying Indigenous brands. #Reconciliation https://lnkd.in/g_ZZybPx 26 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 5,107 followers 1,645 Posts 9 Articles View Profile Connect More from this author Distinguished designer-in-residence Angela DeMontigny mentors students in the School of Fashion on creating ready-to-wear fashion that tells a story Angela DeMontigny 6y International Press Release World Indigenous Fashion Week¬Æ Angela DeMontigny 8y Hamilton's James St. N. is decorating for the HOLIDAYS! Title: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Anthony Viel
Description: Sep 29, 2022  ¬∑  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x¬†...
Extracted_Text:
Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Deloitte Canada | Anthony Viel Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Anthony Viel‚Äôs Post Anthony Viel Chief Executive Officer at Deloitte Canada 2y Report this post In 2020, the Canadian government announced their intention to acknowledge the hardships and injustices #Indigenous communities have faced at the hands of former Canadian leaders. A Truth and Reconciliation Day was announced, and tomorrow we commemorate the second annual recognition of the ongoing need for reconciliation in this country.
¬†
When it comes to #reconciliation , making long-term progress demands that our actions be grounded in accountability and transparency. Deloitte 's Reconciliation Action Plan year-two update report: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation, shares some of the ongoing efforts we have made to fund Indigenous groups and their allies, adapt our systems, and provide resources for our employees to educate themselves about Indigenous culture. The road to reconciliation is long and, at times, challenging, but we continue to strive toward being better listeners and doing our part in contributing to reconciliation efforts. 
¬†
In honour of this important day, we have given our people tomorrow off in the hopes they will use this time to reflect and continue to educate themselves ‚Äì be it attending a workshop, reading a book from an Indigenous author, donating to a local Indigenous-run charity, or learning more about the rich culture and history of Indigenous peoples. On this day, and throughout the year, our primary focus must be to listen, learn, and do our part.¬†We hope our actions will serve as inspiration for others to do the same. https://lnkd.in/gVcfsg7U Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Deloitte Canada www2.deloitte.com 257 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Ailyn Bayubo Sales And Marketing Specialist at LAC Group 2y Report this comment Thanks for posting Like Reply 1¬†Reaction 2¬†Reactions Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 2mo Report this post "It‚Äôs time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions, knowledge, and sovereignty."

As Indigenous peoples, we are not just participants in the economy; we are architects of a system that reflects our interconnectedness, sustainability, and collective prosperity. Economic justice means recognizing our inherent rights, fostering economic reconciliation, and creating pathways for economic sovereignty that benefit all.

We are witnessing a transformative era where Indigenous businesses, entrepreneurs, and nations are reclaiming their rightful place at the economic table. The future is being shaped by Indigenous leadership, collaborative partnerships, and a vision that respects the land, our values, and our people.

Let‚Äôs continue to fuel this momentum. Who wants to play Indigenomics?

Le message port√© par l‚Äô IRD lors de cette s√©quence a mis l‚Äôaccent sur
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†La pertinence, l‚Äôefficacit√© des n√©cessaires transformations pour acc√©l√©rer l‚Äôatteinte des #ODD , trouvent leur fondation dans la science, la technologie et l‚Äôinnovation
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Une science n√©cessairement multidisciplinaire, produite de mani√®re √©quitable et inclusive, "socialement robuste"

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Une science qui doit √™tre encore con√ßue et produite au sein des pays √† faible revenu. 
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Le d√©ploiement des technologies et des innovations doit, se b√¢tir sur des donn√©es FAIR, √™tre inclusive (consid√©rant les connaissances et les besoins des jeunes, des femmes, Peuples Autochtones et Communaut√©s Locales)
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Le d√©ploiement des technologies et des innovations ne doit pas se faire au d√©triment d‚Äôinnovations sociales durables. Il ne doit pas non plus aboutir √† retarder des choix politiques que l‚Äôon sait n√©cessaire.¬†

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Promeut une innovation ouverte‚ÄØaux acteurs publics et socio-√©conomiques locaux

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Collabore avec des entreprises innovantes comme par exemple pour la restauration √† grande √©chelle des √©cosyst√®mes forestiers
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Sensibilise, les jeunes citoyens aux questions de d√©veloppement durable en d√©veloppant des solutions √©ducatives bas√©es sur l'int√©gration de jeux s√©rieux et de simulations scientifiques au sein d'environnements immersifs de r√©alit√© virtuelle ( https://lnkd.in/dqpkHzXz )

Responsable merchandising visuel chez Pr√™te √† relever de nouveaux d√©fis | Expertise en D√©coration 10mo Report this post üåê UN AUTRE TRAIT√â TOTALITAIRE EST EN COURS DE N√âGOCIATIONS...
C'EST √Ä L'OMPI (Organisation mondiale de la propri√©t√© intellectuelle, agence sp√©cialis√©e de l'ONU) CETTE FOIS.
√Ä Gen√®ve encore ! üá®üá≠

L'empire pharma, du digital et du g√©n√©tique tentent par ce trait√© de s'accaparer les savoirs ancestraux des 5000 peuples premiers de la Terre.

Cette conf√©rence de l'OMPI sur les ressources g√©n√©tiques et les connaissances traditionnelles a lieu en ce moment : du 13 au 24 mai 2024.

Le message de Barbara Steudler, qui suit de pr√®s cette affaire :
"Une grosse bataille se joue actuellement √† l'OMPI (WIPO en anglais) avec √† la cl√© un trait√© international sur la propri√©t√© intellectuelle relative √† certaines ressources et savoirs traditionnels des Peuples Autochtones. Concr√®tement, cela veut dire, par ex, pour les HuniKuin (peuple d'Amazonie) que le Kambo, ou l'Ayahuasca et tous leurs autres savoirs indig√®nes sont en jeu dans cette bataille autour de l'appropriation et du brevetage des savoirs traditionnels.

Il n'y a quasiment aucun m√©dia pr√©sent.

Mercredi 23 mai de la semaine prochaine, S√¥nia Guajajara, ministre au gouvernement br√©silien pour les Peuples autochtones, sera pr√©sente ici √† Gen√®ve.

Je suis avec l'√©quipe qui d√©fend les peuples premiers aux c√¥t√©s de Ninawa (chef Huni Kuin pr√©sent actuellement aux n√©gociations) - mais sans droit de vote, qui m'ont demand√© s'il serait possible pour vous de sensibiliser l'opinion pour parler de ces enjeux mondiaux (ou avec S√¥nia Guajajara) : il est sur Gen√®ve jusqu'√† samedi. Sonia sera l√† quant √† elle la semaine prochaine.

N'h√©sitez pas √† diffuser l'information ci-jointe, cela concerne directement les 5000 peuples autochtones de la plan√®te qui sont les gardiens des 80% de la biodiversit√© mondiale et qui se battent pour la Vie.

Pour prendre contact, vous pouvez appeler ou √©crire √† Barbara Steudler (mail : barbara.steudler@nicefuture.com et tel +41 76 324 52 58)"

‚ñ† Source : https://lnkd.in/eyKxKvMT Instrument on Genetic Resources and Associated TK - videos - WIPO Liferay DXP wipo.int 1 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Getrude Alworah 5mo Report this post Gender dynamics play a critical role in agricultural innovations, dissemination and uptake. Day 1 of the Gender Integration for BioInnovate Africa teams workshop, am glad to have contributed to the discussions on  five practical tools for gender integration in bioeconomy projects:
1. Gender Analysis- going beyond understanding the gender roles and power dynamics, and deeper into identifying gender gaps and bridging them.
2. Gender responsive budgeting-ensuring resources are allocated for inclusive participation. 
3. Gender Capacity Building- Designing a gender capacity-building program to ensure farmers, project staff, and community leaders have the skills and knowledge to support inclusive participation.
4. Gender-Sensitive Design and Planning- ensuring project interventions are accessible and beneficial to all. 
5.  Gender-Responsive Monitoring and Evaluation- Develop a gender-responsive monitoring and evaluation (M&E) framework to assess the program‚Äôs impact on men and women. While commercial funding has declined, non-commercial and semi-commercial investors are stepping up to support innovative solutions. This shift towards smaller deals and a focus on early-stage ventures is shaping the future of #agritech in #Africa . 

Gender diversity is crucial for a thriving agritech ecosystem. While there's been an increase in mixed-gender founding teams, all-women-founded teams still face significant challenges. According to Saunders, mixed-gender founding teams saw their share of funding increase from 7% in 2023 to 15% currently. However, all-women-founded teams still account for only 2% of total funding. 

Saunders believes the agritech funding bubble has deflated but can still be sustained. While non-commercial support is crucial, continued commercial interest is needed to prevent further decline. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Kyla Jacobs‚Äô Post Kyla Jacobs Driving Innovation, Strategy, and Growth Across Industries 2y Report this post National Indigenous Economic Strategy (NIES), built and designed exclusively by Indigenous leaders, institutions, and organizations from across¬†Canada unveiled. #strategyandtransformation #indigenomics #buildabetterfuture First Nations Financial Management Board 7,229 followers 2y Growing the Canadian Economy: New National Indigenous Economic Strategy is an economic stimulus for Canada

A coalition of more than 25 National Indigenous Organizations has unveiled a new National Indigenous Economic Strategy (NIES), the first such strategy to be built and designed exclusively by Indigenous leaders, institutions, and organizations from across¬†Canada. 

Research has found that if the gap in opportunities for Indigenous communities was closed, it would result in a boost of more than¬†$30 billion¬†to¬†Canada's¬†GDP.¬†
 
Further, if Indigenous peoples had equitable access to economic opportunities, 135,000 more First Nations, M√©tis, and Inuit individuals would be employed, bringing in¬†$6.9 billion¬†per year in employment income.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenous economy could hit $100B Report this article Jessy Bains Jessy Bains Public relations manager, Indeed Canada Published Nov 27, 2023 + Follow Indigenous business leaders believe their economy is on track to reach $100 billion a year within a few years, reports CBC News . Indigenomics Institute founder Carol Anne Hilton says the number serves as a motivational ‚Äúmarker‚Äù to which Indigenous businesses can aspire. Bill Lomax, CEO of the First Nations Bank of Canada, says that lessons he learned in the U.S. can be used to reach the goal. They include getting governments and companies to increase their use of Indigenous suppliers, as well as expanding the community's presence in the gaming and cannabis industries. Editors‚Äô Picks Lynne Groulx Member of Metis Nation Ontario, human rights defender, resiliency lodge builder, reconciliation believer. 1y Report this post Strategic partnerships with Indigenous-led businesses will create new jobs and opportunities. It also means there is a potential for Indigenous-led businesses to grow into a huge, multi-billion-dollar economy.

What‚Äôs required is a mix of the right policies that Canada does not have right now. We need to ensure government procurement creates space for sourcing from Indigenous-led businesses. We also must see greater alliances between the business community and Indigenous-owned enterprises.

As we‚Äôve seen, Indigenous Women and Gender-Diverse+ Peoples are leading the way in creating new and exciting businesses that make a big impact in their local communities and create economic growth.
Supporting these small businesses with the right tools to grow creates hope.

As Indigenomics CEO Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D said:
‚ÄúI feel very much that this is a powerful time to be alive, where Indigenous people are picking up business as a tool and using it as a stake in the ground to say we're still here." https://lnkd.in/g9TSHaQ7 What is 'Indigenomics'? It's about taking a "constructive, generative approach to economic growth for Indigenous¬†communities to establish the systemic inclusion of Indigenous Peoples in today's modern economy.

Hilton, a¬†member of Hesquiaht First Nation in British Columbia, said she believes it's an antidote to the historical injustice of their exclusion from the economy through discrimination, laws like the Indian Act and Canada's¬†system of reserves.

We believe in equipping individuals with the skills, tools, and innovative tokenomics frameworks needed to lead and shape the technologies of the future, ensuring Indigenous voices are at the forefront of innovation.

Tokenomics represents an opportunity to align traditional Indigenous values, such as reciprocity, sustainability, and community governance, with technology. By leveraging blockchain and decentralized systems, Indigenous communities can create equitable economic models that prioritize long-term prosperity, self-determination, and resource stewardship.

Through our AI, blockchain, and tokenomics training, we‚Äôre addressing historical gaps by providing meaningful pathways for growth, agency, and creativity. This initiative goes beyond education, it‚Äôs about cultivating leaders who can bridge the gap between tradition and technology, driving progress while uplifting Indigenous values and principles.

Together, we are shaping and cultivating a future where Indigenous communities lead with confidence, vision, and impact.

This course is offered completely FREE for Indigenous participants.

This convergence represents a paradigm shift‚Äîone that could democratise global drug access and improve patient outcomes worldwide. But to realise its full potential, collaboration across industries is key.

My spirit is lifted my tenacity is heightened and the partnership opportunities are immense. Networking with this group of strong indigenous women reminded me to be brave‚Ä¶.it‚Äôs not always easy but it‚Äôs necessary to take up space and to be heard! Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Colin Van Loon‚Äôs Post Colin Van Loon Award-winning: Writer, Director, Producer | BFA in Film Studies 1y Report this post So happy to have This IS NOT a Ceremony Indigenomics Institute Indigenomics by DESIGN conference. If you are in Vancouver please take advantage of this opportunity to see This IS NOT a Ceremony. I am always thrilled when the project is available for people who might not own a VR headset to see it in the community. National Film Board of Canada Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Edited With 12 days left to register for the 5th annual Indigenomics by DESIGN event in Vancouver we are offering 20% off 4 ticket packages all week to celebrate the countdown to Indigenomics in ACTION!

The Indigenomics Institute welcomes Deborah B. , Justin Holness , Carol Anne Hilton, MBA , Paul Lacerte , Michelle Bryant-Gravelle , Michael Bonshor , Nathan Grandjambe , Derek Hansom , Mike Werstuik , Joanne Stone-Campbell, MBA , Jeanette (Jen) Turner , Will Harding, MBA , Sarah Best , Kevin Barlow , Bonnie Harvey, Lee Sinclair, Kathryn M. , Alison Tedford Seaweed , Christy Smith-Hadath , Delanie Bulldog, Jay Mearns , Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D , Danalee Baker , Dean Montgomery , Robin Chakrabarti , Mike Campol , Geena Jackson , Chad Rickaby , Darwin Douglas , Flavio Caron , June Anthony-Reeves , Sarah Hrycenko, Lauren Kelly , Leah Bartko , Marissa Nobauer , James Delorme , Lawrence Lewis , Eli Enns to the Indigenomics DESIGN stage! Plus a few more to be announced!

From emerging trends in the 100 Billion Indigenous economy to economic reconciliation action planning these speakers will share their knowledge and expertise on how to advance the 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy in technology, export, finance, human resources, real estate, economic development and more allowing conference attendees to garner the essential tools and knowledge needed to be active participants creating value in the modern economy!

The DESIGN conference will kick off with an Indigenous wine tasting reception Wednesday May 24th led by sommelier Diana Claxton ! This reception is complimentary for registered attendees and for those unable to join the 2-day conference tickets are $45 to attend this unique reception.

During the conference attendees will experience an immersive virtual reality film with Niitsitapi writer and director Ahnahktsipiitaa Colin Van Loon 's cinematic VR experience This Is Not A Ceremony! While also being able to activate economic reconciliation shopping the Indigenomics Market!

Indigenomics events serve to invite leadership, dialogue, and action in advancing the Indigenous economy. We invite you to join us and invite your community! Thank you for being part of Indigenomics in ACTION! Title: #indigenomics #truth #reconciliation | Isobel Alice O'Connell - LinkedIn
Description: Jun 28, 2024  ¬∑  CEO & Founder | Innovative Entrepreneur and Business Strategist, guiding leaders to internationalize their businesses and innovative startups to¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #truth #reconciliation | Isobel Alice O'Connell Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Isobel Alice O'Connell‚Äôs Post Isobel Alice O'Connell Head of Sustainability/ ESG Strategy & Impact :+20yrs Global Exp. in Stakeholder, Issue, Investor & NT Risk Management : Human Rights : Board Director : Named Global 50 Women SustainabilityX Magazine 9mo Edited Report this post Thank you Institute of Corporate Directors Vancouver Chapter and Deloitte Vancouver for hosting an informative member appreciation event on a rainy summer night. 

Thanks Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D for your fireside chat on how boards can recognise the need to set the stage on how to grow the story of Indigenous economic potential through #indigenomics and how companies can truly embrace #truth and #reconciliation . Indigenomics is a collective economic response to the legacy of the systemic exclusion of Indigenous peoples in Canada‚Äôs economic development. It is a platform for economic reconciliation on the balance sheet of Canada, and not being viewed as a liability.

Indigenous groups and communities have celebrated their culture and heritage on June 21 because the significance of summer solstice. National Indigenous People‚Äôs Day is also part of the month long Celebrate Canada program, which also includes Saint Jean-Baptist‚Äôs Day (June 24), Multicultural Day (June 27) and Canada Day (July 1). 

A personal insight, I am starting to see the emerging Indigenous economy best described in the words of Canada‚Äôs greatest ice hockey player, Wayne Gretzky: ‚ÄúSkate to where the puck is going, not where it has been.‚Äù 25 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Michael De Bonis   HBA, CHRE, SHRM, CTI certified. CEO, Breakpoint Human Capital Management, Transition and Performance Coaching for Leaders. Award Winning Chief People + Integrations Officer for Interim or Fractional leadership. Board Member. Keynote Speaker. 9mo Report this post National Indigenous Peoples Day¬†is a day recognizing and celebrating the cultures and contributions of the¬†First Nations,¬†Inuit, and¬†M√©tis¬†Indigenous peoples of Canada.

The day was first celebrated in 1996, after it was proclaimed that year by then¬†Governor General of Canada¬†Rom√©o LeBlanc, to be celebrated annually on June 21.

To build respectful relationships, acknowledging the land is an important part of reconciliation. It honours the authentic history of North America, its original people and tells the story of the creation of this country that has historically been missing.

The indigenous people although they comprise only 6.2% of the world's population, safeguard 80% of the planet's biodiversity. Through diverse community-led actions ‚Äì such as¬†community-owned renewable energy projects, land-based education initiatives, cross-cultural climate conversations, language revitalization programs, and ceremony¬†‚Äì communities are reconnecting with their traditional knowledges, cultures, spiritualities, and lands.

_______

At Breakpoint Human Capital Management we are a trusted advisor and strategic ally to CEO's and executive leaders‚Äô sharpening strategy building organizations that attract, develop, excite, and retain exceptional people. We are proud today to recognize National Indigenous Peoples Day,  the people celebrating, and acknowledge the land where we work.

Breakpoint Human Capital Management
For the people‚Ñ¢ #change #executivecoaching #executiveadvisor #people #nosurprises #strategy #growth #humancapitalmanagement #leadership #entrepreneurship #culture #businesswithpurpose #forthepeople #interimleadership #fractionalleadership 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Tim Penketh CEO, TheFutureEconomy.ca üá®üá¶| Defining a strong vision for Canada's future economy 9mo Report this post This National Indigenous Peoples Day, let‚Äôs celebrate the invaluable contributions of Indigenous communities across Canada and look ahead to what different stakeholders across this country should be doing to uplift Indigenous peoples, leaders and innovations.

From groundbreaking innovations to transformative leadership and partnerships, Indigenous peoples are paving the way for a brighter future. It‚Äôs time to amplify their voices and initiatives, foster employment opportunities, and strengthen collaborations.

Key opportunities:

‚úÖ Support Indigenous innovation: Invest in Indigenous-led startups and initiatives that drive sustainable growth and prosperity
‚úÖ Enhance employment: Create more opportunities for Indigenous employment, improve working conditions, and ensure fair representation in all sectors.
‚úÖ Build strong partnerships: Foster collaborations between Indigenous communities, businesses, and government to drive mutual growth and development.

Our new Future in Focus on National Indigenous Peoples Day features op-eds on these issues from: Patricia Baxter and stephen lindley , Co Chairs of Indigenous Works James Jenkins , Executive Director of Indigenous Clean Energy Kelly Lendsay , Marie Delorme, and Manley Alan Begay, Jr. for Luminary

Read their insights now: https://lnkd.in/ewr2R4mY #NationalIndigenousPeoplesDay #IndigenousInnovation #Leadership #Partnerships #InclusiveFuture #Canada #IndigenousEmployment #SustainableGrowth #CommunityCollaboration #FutureInFocus Future in Focus: National Indigenous Peoples Day - TheFutureEconomy.ca thefutureeconomy.ca 2 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Siddharth Raval Director of Revenue Generation 9mo Report this post Honoring the Contributions of First Nations to Canada's Social Fabric...

Today, I take a moment to express our deepest gratitude and respect for the First Nations communities and their invaluable contributions to the rich, diverse social fabric of Canada.

For thousands of years, First Nations peoples have inhabited and cared for the lands we now call Canada. Their profound knowledge, cultural practices, and spiritual traditions have not only shaped the environment but also the very essence of what it means to be Canadian.

Cultural Heritage: The vibrant art, music, dance, and storytelling traditions of First Nations enrich our cultural mosaic. From the intricate beadwork and carvings to the powerful drum circles and powwows, their creative expressions inspire and unite us.

Stewardship of the Land: First Nations have long been the stewards of the land, advocating for sustainable practices and environmental conservation. Their deep connection to nature teaches us the importance of living in harmony with our surroundings and protecting our planet for future generations.

Community and Values: The values of community, respect, and interconnectedness championed by First Nations serve as a guiding light for all Canadians. Their emphasis on kinship, mutual support, and respect for all living beings offers us a blueprint for a more inclusive and compassionate society.

Wisdom and Knowledge: The wisdom passed down through generations of First Nations Elders and Knowledge Keepers is a treasure trove of understanding and insight. Their teachings on health, governance, and justice enrich our collective knowledge and pave the way for a more equitable future.

As we move forward, it is crucial to continue recognizing and honoring the contributions of First Nations peoples. Let us commit to fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of their cultures, histories, and rights. Together, we can build a Canada that respects and celebrates its First Nations heritage.

Miigwech, Hiy Hiy, and thank you to all First Nations communities for your enduring legacy and for helping to create a stronger, more diverse, and united Canada.

Today, I vouch to contribute towards upskilling you of the First Nations Communities... #FirstNations #Canada #IndigenousHeritage #CulturalDiversity #RespectAndRecognition #Innivec 15 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Terralingua and Langscape Magazine 1,312 followers 9mo Edited Report this post Today, we celebrate National Indigenous Peoples Day, honoring the First Nations, Metis, and Inuit, who contribute significantly to the cultural and social fabric of the country widely known as Canada, located on what some First Nations call Turtle Island.üê¢üçÅ

These Indigenous communities have a long and rich history of resilience, vibrant cultures, and profound wisdom. Despite multiple challenges, they have maintained their unique cultural practices, languages, and traditions for centuries. Their traditional knowledge systems, tested and refined over time, inspire wisdom on sustainable living and community well-being ‚Äì crucial insights in today's ever-evolving world. üåç

As we honor their legacy, we must move beyond recognition and take meaningful actions. ‚úäüèΩ Support First Nations and Indigenous communities worldwide and actively foster reconciliation and justice by advocating for their rights and sovereignty. Together, we can build a future that honors and conserves the biocultural diversity they have nurtured for generations. #IndigenousHistoryMonth #FirstNations #Metis #Inuit #NationaIndigenousPeoplesDay #BioculturalDiversity 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in NOFX Studio 118 followers 10mo Report this post Learning new perspectives about immigration in Canada Arrivance: A Journey of Resilience 147 followers 10mo Edited In 2023 we assisted City of London, Canada ‚ÄúNewcomers Day‚Äù event as part of our pre-development research, and we asked around about the challenges immigrants face when they come to London, Canada.

Here it‚Äôs one of the answers:

‚ÄúI think the biggest challenge for immigrants is communication so finding a way to connect with the other people in their new home and environment and fostering good connections.‚Äù

As we acknowledge the impact of Canada‚Äôs history on Indigenous Peoples, we are reminded of how essential it is to create spaces where every voice is heard and respected.

Respecting and honouring different cultures is not just a responsibility‚Äîit‚Äôs an opportunity to learn, grow, and foster innovation.

By embracing diverse perspectives and actively listening to one another, we create a more inclusive, stronger society. Reconciliation is more than acknowledgment; it‚Äôs about action and mutual respect. #TruthAndReconciliation #DiversityAndInclusion #RespectForCultures #MulticulturalLeadership #GlobalBusiness #ListeningToAllVoices #CanadaStarthub 21 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Half & Half Agency Corp. 278 followers 10mo Report this post Learning new perspectives about immigration in Canada Arrivance: A Journey of Resilience 147 followers 10mo Edited In 2023 we assisted City of London, Canada ‚ÄúNewcomers Day‚Äù event as part of our pre-development research, and we asked around about the challenges immigrants face when they come to London, Canada.

Here it‚Äôs one of the answers:

‚ÄúI think the biggest challenge for immigrants is communication so finding a way to connect with the other people in their new home and environment and fostering good connections.‚Äù

As an organization and as individuals, we recognize and respect:

- The diversity of Indigenous cultures and worldviews and their roles in Canada‚Äôs past, present, and future.

- Our collective responsibility to share natural resources revenues and close gaps in socio-economic conditions between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people. 

- Our role in the journey towards reconciliation by advancing Indigenous knowledge systems in all our work.

- Our privilege to live, work, and play on Indigenous land. 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Coalition for a Better Future 2,160 followers 7mo Report this post Economic reconciliation is crucial for fostering #inclusive #economic #growth , and ensuring that Indigenous Peoples hold leadership positions is a key part of that. 

According to our #Scorecard report ( https://bit.ly/3vEuTCX ), representation of First Nations, Inuit, and M√©tis in management positions ‚¨á decreased to 2.4% in 2023 from 2.7% the previous year. Tabatha Bull , President and CEO of the Canadian Council for Indigenous Business emphasizes the importance of understanding why these numbers declined and suggests three ways for corporate Canada to transform their approach to #recruiting and #retaining Indigenous leadership:

üí° 1) Change the decision-making process at the board level. Consider embracing consensus decision-making and recognize that Indigenous Peoples may take time to assess the long-term impact of decisions on future generations.

üí° 2) Focus on recruiting for potential, not just experience. Relying solely on a candidate's years of experience will restrict the pool of Indigenous talent.

üí° 3) Prioritize intentional training and development. Ensure Indigenous hires receive the necessary training to prepare them for leadership roles.

üì∫ View Tabatha's full comments starting at 2:23:00 https://bit.ly/3Wv8AZI ‚úç Join the conversation. What does economic growth mean to you? #GrowthforAllCdns #BetterFutureforCanada First Nations Finance Authority , First Nations Major Projects Coalition Jesse McCormick , BlackNorth Initiative , Dahabo Ahmed-Omer, Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , Canada's 2SLGBTQI+ Chamber of Commerce (CGLCC) , FCC / FAC , Justine Hendricks , ACCES Employment , Heather Scoffield Patty Hajdu , Jamie Schmale Blake Desjarlais , ‚Ä¶more 6 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in WeBlackSheep 32 followers 2mo Report this post üåç Canada at a Crossroads: Economic & Political Challenges in 2025 üá®üá¶

As we enter 2025, Canadians are navigating a landscape shaped by economic anxiety, regional disparities, and generational divides. Here are some key insights shaping our nation:

üí∞ Economic Anxiety: Rising costs, inflation, and housing unaffordability dominate concerns, creating a ‚Äúscarcity mindset‚Äù that impacts everyday life.

üè° Regional Divisions: From western skepticism of federal climate policies to Ontario‚Äôs housing crisis and Quebec‚Äôs cultural distinctiveness, divisions are stark.

üë• Generational Divide: Fragmented information consumption, older Canadians on traditional media, younger ones on platforms like TikTok, creates challenges for national unity.

üéØ Political Opportunity: With traditional partisan lines blurring, Canadians are looking for bold leadership that prioritizes affordability, job creation, and tangible solutions over ideology.

As voters seek competence and stability, 2025 offers a critical moment for leaders to bridge divides and deliver on economic and social challenges. The path forward will require empathy, innovation, and a commitment to uniting a divided nation.

Title: Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN ...
Description: Nov 27, 2024  ¬∑  Carol Anne Hilton, founder of the Indigenomics Institute, sees a "tidal wave" of Indigenous business growth driven by increased access to capital and improved¬†...
Extracted_Text:
Indigenous people involvement in business on the rise says author - APTN‚Ä¶ | Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN) Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN)‚Äôs Post Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN) 3,828 followers 3mo Report this post üìà A Tidal Wave of Indigenous Entrepreneurship: Insights from Carol Anne Hilton üåä

Carol Anne Hilton, founder of the Indigenomics Institute, sees a "tidal wave" of Indigenous business growth driven by increased access to capital and improved internet in rural areas. Indigenous women, in particular, are leading the way, starting businesses at five times the national rate and securing roles on corporate boards. Hilton, an award-winning leader from the Nuu chah nulth Nation, sees this growth as a step toward economic reconciliation.

According to Hilton, the rise in Indigenous entrepreneurship is also due to a changing mindset in Canada‚Äôs banking sector. As Indigenous leaders now hold positions on the boards of major financial institutions, new doors are opening for Indigenous business ventures.

Hilton‚Äôs book, Indigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table, aims to ignite a $100 billion Indigenous economy. This November, the Indigenomics Institute will host a 24-hour Indigenous global economic forum, spotlighting 36 speakers to discuss the future of Indigenous business.

üåç "We‚Äôre building an ecosystem of successful Indigenous business leaders, providing stories and support to inspire others." ‚Äì Carol Anne Hilton #IndigenousEconomy #Indigenomics #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #EconomicReconciliation #BusinessGrowth https://loom.ly/fcm44aI Indigenous people involvement in business on the rise says author - APTN News https://www.aptnnews.ca 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts CXGLOBE 94 followers 11mo Report this post Traditional knowledge has long been overlooked in the world of business. But now, Indigenous communities are delivering sustainable solutions to a wide range of issues and reshaping the modern economy. 

With more than 476 million Indigenous people living in 90 countries across the world, building positive connections is crucial. And with Indigenous businesses gathering momentum, playing an important role in reshaping modern economies and driving reconciliation, it has become a force that can no longer be ignored.

In Australia, the number of Indigenous businesses increased by more than 47 percent between 2016 and 2021, with their collective contribution to the Australian economy rising at least 59 percent to sit in the range of A$8.5 billion (US$5.5 billion) to A$12 billion (US$7.8 billion).

In Canada, the Indigenous economy was valued at US$35.9 billion in 2020, around 2.2 percent of Canada‚Äôs gross domestic product. The Toronto-based Indigenomics Institute is confident it is on track to more than triple in size and is working to secure the Indigenous business sector‚Äôs place at the table.

In New Zealand, the last 10 years has seen the MƒÅori asset base grow at a significantly faster rate than the overall economy to a current valuation of more than US$42.5 billion. According to forecasts, it will reach US$60.8 billion by 2030.

In modern business, we seem to forget the symbiotic nature of ‚Äòwho‚Äô we are delivering to, and only focus on ‚Äòwhat‚Äô we are doing. Traditional business, on the other hand, is always¬†focused on relationships before the business. 

If the founders and entrepreneurs focus on building these relationships and solve for real-world problems, we will create greater value for not only those communities but for the whole world, while protecting traditions and creating the world a better place. #entrepreneurship #innovation #problemsolving #indigenousbusinesses Harnessing Indigenous innovation boosts opportunities for all theceomagazine.com 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Anmol Rattan Singh Policy Researcher | Co-Founder, PANJ Foundation 7mo Report this post I read this interesting piece a while back, and here‚Äôs my brief take on it. https://lnkd.in/giEyPVPd It's safe to say that most of us are acutely aware that the bedrock of development in Punjab‚Äîand indeed, across the Global South‚Äîrests on the shoulders of knowledge equity. The notion of providing economic advisory support is not just about offering expertise; it's about empowering local voices, fostering innovation, and challenging the entrenched hierarchies of perspectives.

Punjab, with its dynamic socio-economic landscape, is uniquely positioned to lead by example. Yet, we must confront the reality that knowledge inequities have often stifled our region's potential to influence its own development trajectory. When foreign experts dominate the discourse, we risk sidelining the very voices that are most attuned to the complexities and nuances of our local context.

At PANJ (Policy Advisory and Network for Joint Progress) Foundation, we believe that true progress in Punjab requires an entrepreneurial approach to redressing these inequities. This isn't merely a matter of fairness‚Äîit's a strategic imperative. This diversity is crucial, especially when grappling with the "wicked" problems that require innovative, interdisciplinary solutions.

We must also redefine what it means to be an "expert". Expertise should be recognised not solely by published papers or foreign credentials but by an individual's deep understanding of local contexts and their capacity to innovate within them. This redefinition can unlock a wealth of untapped potential within Punjab, ensuring that our region's development is driven by those who live and breathe its challenges and opportunities.

Moreover, addressing knowledge inequities in Punjab is not just about levelling the playing field‚Äîit's about future-proofing our economic and development strategies. By investing in local talent and fostering strategic partnerships, we can build robust knowledge systems that are resilient and adaptable to the demands of an ever-evolving global economy.

The time for action is now. Let us engage in this critical dialogue, challenge the status quo, and together, lay the foundation for a more equitable and prosperous future for Punjab. PANJ Foundation is committed to being at the forefront of this movement, and we invite thinkers, innovators, and change-makers to join us in this mission. Dr. Rajwant Singh | Harjeet Singh | Jalnidh Kaur | Dr Madan M Singh AULAKH | Dr. Preet Deep Singh | Gauravdeep Singh | Tejpreet Chopra | Manmohan (Mac) Sarin | Navkaran Singh | Dr. Harmeet Singh | Narain Batra | Satinder Grover | Amarjit Singh | Vikram R Singh | Sehaj Singh | Karan Avtar Singh | Surinder S. The project had two interconnected aims: to represent the #socialeconomy of today based on current data as well as to identify methodological and operational tools to improve this representation. The study collects and analyses quantitative and qualitative data the social economy ecosystem as well as their contribution to a sustainable, innovative and resilient economy and society. 

üìä¬†Key figures:
üîπAt least 11.5 million people‚Äîrepresenting 6.3% of the employed population‚Äîare engaged in the social economy.
üîπAcross the 27 EU Member States, the social economy comprises over 4.3 million entities.
üîπMore¬†than 246,000 social enterprises have been identified.
¬†
It was a fascinating experience working on this emerging topic alongside Euricse and CIRIEC International (via CIRIEC-Espa√±a ). A special thank you to our team leader Silke N. Haarich Haarich and team members Sandra Spule , Marcela M√§der Furtado , Kirsti Hagemann , and Jean Claude Zeimet for their excellent collaboration.
