Columnist/writer for rabble.ca. 8mo Edited Report this post Recently, Canadian busines leaders, elites, and small biz associations are whispering "productivity" to each other like McGuire, the uncle, purred the word "plastics" into 
Dustin Hoffman‚Äôs Benjamin's ear as the ultimate "secret to success" advice in the movie, The Graduate.

Productivity. Conservatives, bank and think tank studies, and rhetoric in media is already mounting. It will emerge as a slick, manufactured election issue for Canadians. 

Increased productivity, meaning essentially increasing sales, removing regulatory hurdles, while producing more, faster at lower cost, increases GDP, and the potential to create wealth ---for all but in truth, primarily for foreign/domestic owners/ shareholders. Trickle down economics rhetoric rides again. 

Investment in productivity centered tech and innovation is not in itself bad. The issue is where the wealth it creates goes. 

Not to us.

Surely we have learned?

In this time in our collective history, GDP growth via increased productivity with continued ecological rape and significant increase in taxation of corporate wealth created is the wrong thing to focus on if we want all life to thrive and live in balance.  In today's world, that means reclaiming, increasing funding to, and public soverign control of land, housing, healthy local food, healthcare, essential infrastructure, and investment in and all-access to world class education opportunities. 

A corporate and business elite defined and motivated productivity agenda helps the few and not the many. Don't be fooled. Again. 

If The Graduate was re made today, I like to believe it would feature a loving radical, modern socialist, intersectional feminist Aunty, in clear voice at a Palestinian protest rally (not a Rosedale party) passionately cupping Benjamin's face, saying honey, its "peace, solidarity, post growth economics". #postgrowth #productivity Growth is enriching an elite and killing the planet. We need an economy based on human rights | Olivier De Schutter theguardian.com 16 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Omer Abdalla Community Builder and Serial Entrepreneur 10mo Edited Report this post Economic reconciliation with Indigenous communities is not just a moral imperative, but also a significant opportunity for all Canadian business owners. It's about fostering partnerships that respect Indigenous sovereignty, culture, and rights, and creating economic opportunities that benefit both Indigenous and non-Indigenous Canadians.

Today I got to hear from leading experts in the field of Indigenous Economic reconciliation. Lindsay Brant, M.Ed, PhD Candidate (ABD). , Jarret Leaman , Rhode Thomas , Shyra Barberstock, PhD , Rye Karonhiowanen Barberstock, PhD , spoke beautifully on the colonial systems that exist within Canada, and the barriers to breaking down said systems.

For many years, the economic marginalization of Indigenous communities has contributed to the socio-economic gaps that we see today. Economic reconciliation seeks to address these disparities by ensuring that Indigenous peoples have equitable access to resources, opportunities, and decision-making processes. The Canadian Government follows a requirement for federal departments and agencies ensures a minimum 5% of the total value of contracts are held by Indigenous businesses, a number in line with the population percentage of Indigenous peoples on Turtle Island.

Investing in Indigenous partnerships means tapping into rich cultural heritage, innovative business practices, and a growing market of consumers who value social responsibility. It‚Äôs a chance to learn from each other and build a more inclusive economy that respects and incorporates Indigenous knowledge and traditions. 

I learned today that the Land we live on can be seen as curriculum, a curriculum we need to understand, respect, and implement in our business practices. 

How are you incorporating principles of economic reconciliation in your business? I would love to hear practical solutions I myself could implement!

Together, let‚Äôs honour the land we are on. I acknowledge that I live and work on the traditional territories of the Mississaugas of the Credit, the Anishinaabe, the Haudenosaunee, and the Wendat peoples. 14 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Pharis Mavia Sales representative at LEJA.  
cybersecurity analyst.
CEO CyberVault.
Director at Catering angels üçúüç≤ 4mo Report this post Today, we gather to celebrate the incredible strides made by many countries that were once labeled as "third world" nations. These countries, often underestimated, have demonstrated resilience, adaptability, and ambition, transforming challenges into remarkable growth stories. The term "third world" may imply a position behind the rest of the world, but the reality we see today tells a different story‚Äîone of rapid development, innovation, and a drive to reshape their futures.

One of the driving forces behind this economic growth is the entrepreneurial spirit that thrives in these nations. With young, ambitious populations, many countries are investing in small and medium enterprises, providing platforms for job creation and wealth generation at the grassroots level. This momentum has paved the way for a burgeoning middle class, which, in turn, stimulates demand for goods, services, and infrastructure.

Moreover, we cannot overlook the role of technology in this transformation. Mobile technology, for instance, has redefined access to banking and financial services, particularly in regions where traditional banking infrastructure is limited. In East Africa, for example, mobile payment systems like M-Pesa have revolutionized commerce, enabling millions to participate in the economy without needing a bank account. This digital revolution is creating unprecedented opportunities for financial inclusion and economic participation.

Another crucial factor in this economic growth is the commitment of these countries to invest in education and skill development. Governments are increasingly prioritizing education, recognizing that a skilled workforce is vital to a competitive economy. From vocational training programs to partnerships with international educational institutions, these investments are equipping the youth with the tools they need to succeed in the global market.

Foreign direct investment (FDI) has also played a pivotal role. Investors worldwide are recognizing the potential of emerging markets and are channeling funds into industries such as manufacturing, agriculture, technology, and renewable energy. In fact, some of the world‚Äôs fastest-growing economies today are in Africa and Southeast Asia, where foreign investments are creating jobs and infrastructure and driving exports.

Ladies and gentlemen, while these achievements are cause for celebration, there is still much work ahead. Many of these nations continue to face challenges related to income inequality, political stability, and environmental sustainability. However, the positive trajectory we see today gives us reason for optimism. With continued commitment to sustainable growth, investment in people, and innovation, these countries are well on their way to shaping a future where they stand not behind but alongside the world‚Äôs most developed economies.

Let us be inspired by their journey and look forward to a world where opportunity, prosperity, and success are truly global. 6 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in GOALOOP¬Æ - Connecting the World through Goals¬Æ 615 followers 9mo Report this post Shrink the #Economy , Save the World?

Economic #growth has been ecologically costly ‚Äî and so a movement in favor of ‚Äòdegrowth‚Äô is growing. Techno-optimists place their faith in #innovation ; degrowthers place theirs in social movements. Both sides lay claim to being the genuine realists. Each insists that we simply don‚Äôt have enough time to do what the other side wants.

‚ÄúGains in economic growth have too often buoyed the fortunes of the richest instead of lifting all boats. Prosperity even in the most prosperous countries hasn‚Äôt been shared. But all the attention to #inequality is just a crack in the edifice of economic orthodoxy. Now a much more radical proposition has emerged, looming like a wrecking ball: Is economic growth desirable at all?

[...] today there is a burgeoning ‚Äúpost-growth‚Äù and ‚Äúdegrowth‚Äù movement [...] 

‚ÄòA Poverty of Imagination‚Äô

Given how keenly the degrowth movement disavows coercion, how is this wholesale transformation supposed to happen? ‚ÄúSeeds of degrowth communism are sprouting all over the world,‚Äù Saito writes, pointing to experiments in local governance in cities like Barcelona, which has pledged to be carbon neutral by 2050, and farming cooperatives in South Africa.

Even degrowth‚Äôs skeptics may find that Saito‚Äôs examples of grass-roots organizing sound agreeably democratic and improvisational. But the prospect of global apocalypse that degrowthers keep emphasizing also has the perverse effect of making local measures sound acutely inadequate. Still, Saito says that such experiments do offer something crucial: an enlarged sense of what‚Äôs possible. Degrowth‚Äôs critics, he writes, suffer from ‚Äúa poverty of imagination that simply accepts the status quo as unchangeable.‚Äù

As it happens, Susskind says precisely the same thing but in the reverse: that it‚Äôs degrowth‚Äôs advocates who suffer from a ‚Äúlack of imagination.‚Äù The mirrored accusations are striking. Maybe it isn‚Äôt a matter so much of imagination scarcity as of where that imagination is directed. Techno-optimists place their faith in innovation; degrowthers place theirs in social movements. Both sides lay claim to being the genuine realists. Each insists that we simply don‚Äôt have enough time to do what the other side wants.

The intransigence of such zero-sum disputes is a reminder of why win-win fantasies are so attractive in the first place. Whatever the profound differences between degrowth‚Äôs proponents and their critics, the scale of the climate crisis suggests one point of convergence: We need all the imaginative help we can get.‚Äù

By Jennifer Szalai https://lnkd.in/embXvJSc #economy #markets #growth #revenue #income #justice #socialmobility #climatechange #AI #democracy #goals #connectgoals #goalmarket #technology #equality #health #humanity Shrink the Economy, Save the World? https://www.nytimes.com 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center 5,602 followers 5mo Report this post üåç New report about the #SocialEconomy published by the European Commission ! üöÄ

We are proud to share that two reports from the Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center and the NOVA SBE Data Science Knowledge Center have been referenced in the report ‚ÄúBenchmarking the Socio-Economic Performance of the EU Social Economy.‚Äù

This comprehensive report highlights the crucial role of the social economy across 27 EU Member States, with over 4.3 million entities employing at least 11.5 million people.

At the Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center , we are committed to building the capacity of social organizations, empowering them to deepen their impact and operational efficiency. Title: Mason Ducharme | 16 comments - LinkedIn
Description: Jun 16, 2024  ¬∑  D. Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author¬†...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenousscholarships #educationequity #stoppretendians‚Ä¶ | Mason Ducharme | 16 comments Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Mason Ducharme‚Äôs Post Mason Ducharme PhD | Indigenous Executive & Capacity-Building Scholar | Specialist in Indigenous Governance 9mo Report this post üì¢ Calling for a Change: Strengthening Verification for Indigenous Scholarships

Over the past 15 years, I suspect that over $1,000,000 of Indigenous-specific post-secondary scholarships and bursaries have been accessed by pretendians. This misuse highlights a significant flaw in the current self-identification process for some scholarships, which often requires no documentation to prove Indigenous identity.

Many post-secondary institutions and private sector businesses allow applicants to self-identify as Indigenous without requiring any proof. In contrast, Indigenous organizations such as the National Indian Brotherhood Trust, Chief Joe Mathias, and Lilwat Nation mandate documentation like a status card or a community letter.

Having been in post-secondary education since 2010, I‚Äôve observed that only about 20% of recipients of Indigenous scholarships or bursaries seemed authentically Indigenous, explicitly sharing their community, language, and culture. The remaining 80%, often vaguely identifying as M√©tis without specifying their community, appeared to exploit the self-identification process, thereby diverting much-needed financial support from genuinely Indigenous students.

The case of the Gill twins is a notable example of this exploitation going unpunished, and I believe there are many more cases out there. It‚Äôs clear that the self-identification process is flawed and primarily benefits pretendians.

We must eliminate self-identification for Indigenous scholarships to ensure that resources dedicated to Indigenous Peoples are used to close the socioeconomic gap for those who truly need and deserve it. #IndigenousScholarships #EducationEquity #StopPretendians #AuthenticityMatters 117 16 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Roxanne M. Learning my Sechelt Language 9mo Report this comment What I have found is that institutions will not question their identity.  I have met some individuals who have ticked that box and I know and they know they are not indigenous but receive bursaries, etc meanwhile the student who is working hard and is recognized by their band is overlooked. Like Reply 2¬†Reactions 3¬†Reactions Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 9mo Report this comment We ask the communitues to select the recipients of our Indigenomics scholarships. Thats a big number! Like Reply 30¬†Reactions 31¬†Reactions Jayden Ode'imin Creative Designer at Sky Story Creative 9mo Report this comment Hi Mason, you are so right! I'm working for a software company looking to bring change in how we verify authentic Indigenous peoples, while still including those who have been in the child welfare system and may not have a 'community.' Would love to chat more! Like Reply 2¬†Reactions 3¬†Reactions Nicholas Hampton Earth | Alberta, Canada
I am your Leader 9mo Report this comment This is an example of where I definitely feel the word pretendian is justified and needs attention and to be addressed immediately.

You are correct in your believed that there are more cases like this where people are taking advantage and fraudulently claiming benefits. There‚Äôs organizations that are involved in this and recommending it to clients.

I am hearing of African folks who just arrived utilizing benefits on top of other stuff and it‚Äôs just insane. 

There  all kinds of groups that have been funded by government that are getting extra money claiming to serve indigenous people and communities and it‚Äôs totally a scam, they offer something that they put together but have never served an indigenous person nor do they plan to. Environmental groups also preying on indigenous to obtain funding. It‚Äôs sick, so hard to trust anyone‚Ä¶ would be nice to get to a point where we don‚Äôt depend on government money and be able to protect it.

This is actually an issue that matters and not the nonsense of shaming someone for having feathers in their hair.

This needs to be shut down for sure, please let me what steps we can take to stop this. Reporting them is difficult I think there needs to be an audit and some legislation to prevent this. Like Reply 1¬†Reaction Shannin Metatawabin ICD.D CEO at National Aboriginal Capital Corporation Association (NACCA) 9mo Report this comment Very important and evolving conversation.  Self identifying should be eliminated immediately.  If your Indigenous,  do the work to demonstrate.   All institutions and support systems need to raise standards to a process of demonstrated verification.  If Australia is doing it,  lessons exist. Like Reply 3¬†Reactions 4¬†Reactions Stephen Didzena Resource Development Consultant at Denetha' 8mo Report this comment The biggest hurdle is to fear education as the tool to assimilation Like Reply 1¬†Reaction Liz Barrett Math Evangelist ,Professional Learning & Educator Support Specialist  (Northern and Western Canada & Indigenous Initiatives), Nature Photographer - Environmental Activist - My views are mine alone! 9mo Report this comment The podcast" Pretendian  Hunters," created by Robert Jago and Angel Ellis is shocking - the most disturbing is  Episode 2 on pretending in prison - truly horrific, especially if you are Indigenous ! https://www.canadaland.com/shows/pretendians / Like Reply 5¬†Reactions 6¬†Reactions Nicholas Hampton Earth | Alberta, Canada
I am your Leader 9mo Report this comment They say that this is a ‚Äúcomplex issue‚Äù but it actually is not. The government just needs a solution that works.

The main problem is that these schools and programs they don‚Äôt care, not at all, cos for them it‚Äôs guaranteed enrolment and money.

I personally don‚Äôt have a problem with someone  doing this that is not native but is a supporter and advocate and has a solid understanding of the culture and like whatever‚Ä¶.

BUT if someone is doing this for the purposes of just taking advantage and not contributing anything to indigenous culture or straight up taking it away from potential candidates then that is very wrong and this issue has now escalated to a point where it‚Äôs out of control.

I truly feel like the #1 issue is that the benefits and burseries are just simply not advertised to the indigenous communities enough. There needs to be some kind of rule or campaign where they are actively going to people who need these programs the most, and making them aware that it‚Äôs available, that would start filling up spots and weeding out the bad seeds. Like Reply 1¬†Reaction See more comments To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Patricia Prince Indigenous Relations Lead at United Way British Columbia 9mo Report this post Having sat on committees to disburse millions in scholarships & bursaries - this has definitely been an issue & a topic that has been brought up EVERY year! Without having to disclose how I weeded through applications that had very high likelihood of being a ‚Äúpretendian‚Äù - it‚Äôs definitely a thing! 

I absolutely without a doubt strongly recommend that this be addressed - that there needs to be verification & at the very least something that points toward being authentic indigenous and a person whose been impacted by residential school, 60‚Äôs scoop or Bill C-31.  

Because the flip side of this - is sometimes we‚Äôve got applicants who‚Äôve been severely impacted by 60‚Äôs scoop, Bill C-31 or the enfranchisement act to name a few where there needs to be special considerations where there is no proof of First Nations, metis or Inuit status. 

These acts where people don‚Äôt qualify take away from those who should be getting the scholarships & bursaries & honestly it‚Äôs theft, it‚Äôs lying, it‚Äôs cheating.  

Great way to start careers - just saying! Mason Ducharme PhD | Indigenous Executive & Capacity-Building Scholar | Specialist in Indigenous Governance 9mo üì¢ Calling for a Change: Strengthening Verification for Indigenous Scholarships

Over the past 15 years, I suspect that over $1,000,000 of Indigenous-specific post-secondary scholarships and bursaries have been accessed by pretendians. This misuse highlights a significant flaw in the current self-identification process for some scholarships, which often requires no documentation to prove Indigenous identity.

Many post-secondary institutions and private sector businesses allow applicants to self-identify as Indigenous without requiring any proof. In contrast, Indigenous organizations such as the National Indian Brotherhood Trust, Chief Joe Mathias, and Lilwat Nation mandate documentation like a status card or a community letter.

Having been in post-secondary education since 2010, I‚Äôve observed that only about 20% of recipients of Indigenous scholarships or bursaries seemed authentically Indigenous, explicitly sharing their community, language, and culture. The remaining 80%, often vaguely identifying as M√©tis without specifying their community, appeared to exploit the self-identification process, thereby diverting much-needed financial support from genuinely Indigenous students.

The case of the Gill twins is a notable example of this exploitation going unpunished, and I believe there are many more cases out there. It‚Äôs clear that the self-identification process is flawed and primarily benefits pretendians.

We must eliminate self-identification for Indigenous scholarships to ensure that resources dedicated to Indigenous Peoples are used to close the socioeconomic gap for those who truly need and deserve it. #IndigenousScholarships #EducationEquity #StopPretendians #AuthenticityMatters 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 247Update News 457 followers 5mo Report this post Pakistan's Ministry of Religious Affairs established scholarships for non-Muslim students to improve educational prospects for the country's minority communities, which make up fewer than 5% of the total population. The government is committed to encouraging inclusivity through programs like as the Prime Minister's Minority Scholarship Scheme and the Pakistan Minorities Scholarship Program. 

These programs provide financial assistance for tuition, stipends, book allowances, and travel awards depending on academic performance, financial need, and citizenship.

A ministry spokeswoman noted that applications for scholarships for the current fiscal year will be filed online via the ministry's website. This initiative has received around $210,000 (Rs60 million) in funding. Non-Muslim students in government institutions must have at least 50% of their marks and submit the necessary papers to be considered eligible. #Pakistan #EducationForAll #MinorityScholarships #Inclusivity #ReligiousAffairs #traders #setback #dollar #247newsupdate 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in EU Today 821 followers 2mo Report this post The European Union has long supported global education initiatives overseas, including in Pakistan.

In 2022, the EU allocated ‚Ç¨10 million to Sindh province to strengthen provincial education policies, as part of broader funding under the EU Multi-Annual Indicative Programme 2021‚Äì2027.

While this financial assistance is aimed at improving educational standards and accessibility, recent concerns have emerged over the potential misuse of these funds, raising questions about transparency and accountability. #EUToday #Pakistan EU Funding for Education in Pakistan Sparks Concerns Over Religious Indoctrination https://eutoday.net 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in International Economic Association 529 followers 5mo Report this post üåç Addressing Colonial Legacy in Education: Insights from Tunisia üìö

In a thought-provoking article, Maleke Fourati, Associate Professor at the South Mediterranean University ‚Äì Mediterranean School of Business (SMU-MSB), currently on leave at the University of French Polynesia, explores the lingering effects of colonial influence on educational institutions in #Tunisia .

The study reveals that the enrolment of Tunisian students in colonial primary schools has significantly influenced literacy rates for decades. Notably, a 1% increase in enrolment in 1931 is linked to an approximate 1.8 percentage point rise in literacy by 2014. This enduring legacy highlights education‚Äôs crucial role in breaking the cycle of poverty.

Since gaining independence, Tunisia has made remarkable progress in reducing educational disparities, achieving near-universal primary education by 2014. However, challenges persist, especially regarding the quality of education.

Fourati stresses that while our history impacts our present, it doesn‚Äôt dictate our future. By implementing effective policies and investing consistently in education, we can create a brighter path ahead. #Education #Tunisia #ColonialLegacy #Literacy #PolicyImpact Read here https://bit.ly/4eMQD0s Addressing the lingering effects of colonial influence on educational institutions cepr.org 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Pak-Afghan Youth Forum 725 followers 2mo Report this post Pakistan‚Äôs Commitment to Muslim Girls' Education at the Global Conference 

The Intl' Conference on Girls‚Äô Education in Muslim Communities was convened as part of a global effort to address the educational challenges faced by girls, particularly in conflict-affected regions, including Afghanistan.

The conference brought together a diverse group of stakeholders, including governments, Islamic scholars, international organizations & educational advocates, to discuss & promote girls‚Äô education in underserved areas. https://lnkd.in/dNhgXsDX International Conference on Girls‚Äô Education in Muslim Communities Highlights IEA's Regressive Policies - Pak Afghan Youth Forum https://pkafgyouthforum.com 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous Corporate Training Inc. 4,120 followers 7mo Report this post This is a follow-up to the statistics Canada article we shared today about the early career quality of Indigenous graduates.

Lower Education - #2 of¬†8 Key Issues for Indigenous Peoples in Canada https://hubs.la/Q02JXBLN0 Lower Education - #2 of¬†8 Key Issues for Indigenous Peoples in Canada ictinc.ca 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Dr. Hamidah Babirye Nsereko Procurement, Logistics and Supply Chain Expert & Lecturer
Department of Procurement & Supply Chain Management at Makerere University Business School 4mo Report this post The age restrictions imposed by many scholarship programs targeting Africans are not only unrealistic but also profoundly unjust. Imagine a PhD scholarship for a needy African with an age limit of 35 years. Such limitations fail to acknowledge the unique challenges faced by numerous African students, thereby denying opportunities to those who have demonstrated immense resilience and determination. In many African countries, the journey to higher education is anything but straightforward. It is a path marked by significant personal sacrifice and unwavering perseverance. Many students start going to School late due to the long walk from home to school and back. In other cases, along the way, many students must balance their studies with work to support themselves and their families, which requires taking breaks from their education to earn money or dealing with life events such as early marriage or pregnancy, further delaying their academic progress. Such realities make it impossible for many African students to adhere to traditional educational timelines. So, when scholarships impose age limits, they exclude those who have had to navigate these non-traditional paths. I feel that a student who has worked for years to save for university fees or a young mother returning to school after raising her children is no less deserving of financial aid than someone who followed a more conventional route. 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Patrick Otundo Educator, Instructional Designer, Author, Writer 4mo Report this post A Brief History of Education in Kenya During the Pre-Colonial and Colonial Epochs

The education system has evolved from the pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial right into the 21st century, influenced chiefly by individuals and committees appointed by the government. 

Since of these individuals were appointed by the government, most of their recommendations were based on prevailing political realities. This article describes how the Kenyan education system has evolved over the years.

Pre-colonial Education

Even though formal schooling was unheard of before the Europeans arrived in Kenya, there existed a form of education whose primary aim was acculturation or transmission of culture from generation to generation. 

The purpose of education in pre-colonial Kenya was to teach the community‚Äôs cultural practices to the young. 

The philosophy of education at that time tended to be more pragmatic as the older members of society would spend time teaching children the skills they needed for their day-to-day survival.

Colonial Education

During the colonial era, education was mainly to convert Africans to Christianity and create a skilled labor force for the colonial enterprise. 

Africans were required to acquire practical skills such as agriculture, carpentry, and masonry to work for European settlers. 

This happened in both missionary and government schools across the country. 

The first formal school in Kenya was established in 1846 by Ludwig Krapf and Johan Rebmann, two missionaries working with the Church Missionary Society (CMS).

According to Mackatiani C. et al., education before the 1908 Fraser Commission did not discriminate against students on account of their race.

The Fraser Commission was the first to recommend the segregation of the education system, with Africans getting training in practical skills, Indians in technical skills, and Europeans in academic-oriented disciplines. 

From the early 1920s to the early 1930s, the government established schools in Narok, Kericho, Kajiado, Tambach, Loitoktok, Kakamega, and Kagumo. 

In 1949, Beecher led a government-appointed committee to establish the Royal Technical College, which became the University of Nairobi. 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Startup Pakistan 761,582 followers 5mo Report this post Pakistan‚Äôs Ministry of Religious Affairs announced scholarships aimed at non-Muslim students to enhance educational opportunities for minority communities, which constitute less than 5% of the population. The government is committed to promoting inclusivity through initiatives like the Prime Minister‚Äôs Minority Scholarship Scheme and the Pakistan Minorities Scholarship Program. 

These programs offer financial support covering tuition, stipends, book allowances, and travel grants based on academic merit, financial need, and citizenship.

A ministry spokesman stated that applications for this financial year's scholarships will be submitted online through the ministry's website. Approximately $210,000 (Rs60 million) has been allocated for this initiative. Eligibility requires non-Muslim students in government institutions to have scored at least 50% marks and to provide necessary documentation. #Pakistan #EducationForAll #MinorityScholarships #Inclusivity #ReligiousAffairs 574 17 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Yemi Ajayi Faculty Member, Researcher, Mediapreneur, Artist 3mo Report this post A BALANCED APPROACH TO Tertiary Education Trust Fund Tetfund 'S SUSPENSION OF FOREIGN #SCHOLARSHIPS Following the release of the memorandum announcing #TETFund 's decision to suspend foreign scholarships, a wave of responses has emerged across #academic circles and social media platforms. A significant portion of these submissions, rather than fostering constructive dialogue, have sought to rally academic #unions against the agency. This rising tide of dissent calls for a measured and intellectually grounded response, one that transcends emotion and embraces reason, offering a balanced perspective on this critical issue.

While it is understandable that some may feel concerned about the suspension of foreign scholarships by TETFund, it is important to approach this issue with a balanced and pragmatic perspective.

1. The Temporary Nature of the Suspension:
The word suspension signifies a temporary halt, not a permanent decision. This suggests that the program can be reinstated once the underlying challenges are addressed.

2. Valid Reasons for the Suspension:
TETFund has cited two key issues:

Abuse of the Scholarship: Unfortunately, many beneficiaries now view the scholarship as a pathway to permanent emigration ( _Japa_ ), rather than a means to gain #knowledge and return to contribute to #national #development (A grave concern).

Exchange Rate Crisis: With the #naira struggling against the #dollar , the funds that once supported thousands will now barely cover a few, through no fault of the agency.

3. Empathy and Pragmatism:
If we were in the position of the TETFund Secretary, would we continue to fund a program that yields diminishing returns? The logical decision would be to pause, reassess, and explore alternative solutions.


4. The Way Forward:
Rather than inciting unions against TETFund, we should encourage constructive engagement. Key unions/stakeholders such as #ASUU , #ASUP , et.al , can:

Collaborate with TETFund to design programs that prevent abuse, such as mandatory return clauses (With more severe consequences for any breach of agreement) and post-scholarship monitoring.

Advocate for Alternative #Solutions , such as domestic scholarships with #international collaboration or short-term overseas training.

Engage with the #Government to address the exchange rate issue or increase funding for education.

This is a call for responsibility and collaboration, not confrontation. By working together, we can restore the integrity of the scholarship program and ensure it serves its original purpose, which is tailored towards advancing Nigeria‚Äôs #academic and #economic development.

Caveat:
I personally have no affiliation with TETFund or any political entity, I have not benefitted from the scholarship, so it won't be construed as a beneficiary defending his benefactor, I do not know the executive secretary from Adam, but as an academic, I believe in standing tall for what is right and feasible always.

Extracted_Text:
#esg #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #tahltan #mining‚Ä¶ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D | 51 comments Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D‚Äôs Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 1y Edited Report this post Today marks my last official day with Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) . It has been an incredible journey with some amazing progress made in a very short period of time. 

Key accomplishments that stand out for me:

- Bringing an amazing Sr. Leadership team together. The best I have ever had the honour of working with.

- Building out the drivers license, mentorship and Heavy Equipment Operators (HEO) programs to help our members and employees into cool jobs and advancing in their perspective careers.

- Revamping the safety program with a significant shift in safety culture and the roadmap to achieving COR certification. 

- Significant advancement for finance and accounting through outsourced payroll with an online tool to enhance employee value, shift in fiscal year end to improve reporting for the shareholder and a plan to go from a review to an audit.  

- Shift in construction delivery from time and materials into fixed bids. Becoming the general contractor for the TIA at Red Chris mine site and a refreshed fleet with a progressive maintenance program. 

- A focus on employee experience through the first employee survey (we did 2 to date), enhanced compensation and benefits, employee recognition program and exit interviews. 

- Enhanced communication plan with a brand refresh, 2 comprehensive reports per year, rich social media program and regular community engagement. 

I want to thank all of the dedicated TNDC employees. An amazing Sr. Leadership team.  A caring board of directors. A supportive community. Excellent industry and business partners that have supported us through our journey to date. 

Much awesomeness has been achieved and the journey is far from over. TNDC is growing and quickly being a national leader. 

Proud to be a small part of it all. 

Meduh (Thank you)!!!

Here are some of my favourite pictures over the last couple of years that I think captures the journey nicely. This event is an invaluable opportunity to explore the world of business, explore the vast array of opportunities available at Naawi-Oodena, and gain invaluable networking opportunities with a variety of influential business leaders from all sectors.

Join us for two enriching days filled with networking, learning, and discovery. Whether you're an experienced professional eager to broaden your horizons or a budding entrepreneur seeking your next venture, this event promises something for everyone.

In this episode, we had the privilege of speaking with Dr. Moses Alobo , a distinguished physician, public health expert, and social impact entrepreneur, about the critical role of African voices in driving scientific innovation. Dr. Alobo leads the Science Innovation and Entrepreneurship team at the Science for Africa Foundation , where he works tirelessly to bridge the gap between cutting-edge science and the unique needs of the African continent.

In this insightful conversation, Dr. Alobo shared his vision for a future where scientific advancements are deeply rooted in local challenges, creating solutions that resonate with the realities on the ground. He emphasized the importance of aligning innovations with market demands, highlighting how science must respond to the specific needs of African communities to truly make an impact.

üí¨ ‚ÄúWhat I would really like to do is to make sure that health innovations, scientific innovations on the African continent, are actually working towards local problems. For the longest time, our intelligent minds on the African continent have been used for science that is important for problems that are not on the African continent.‚Äù - Dr. Moses Alobo This episode offers a behind-the-scenes look at the intersection of innovation, entrepreneurship, and the urgent need to address the unique challenges faced by Africa. 

üéß Tune in now to learn more about Dr. Alobo's groundbreaking work and his mission to push local science forward. #CTDPodAfrica #CTDPodRecap #ScienceLeaders #SciComm #Innovation #AfricanScience #Entrepreneurship #LocalSolutions #ScienceForAfrica #PublicHealth #TechForGood üîó https://lnkd.in/dY6PViWK View C2PA information Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Africa Business Club (ABC) at  Johns Hopkins Carey Business School Join ABC and maximize your networking and collaboration potentials. At the Pan African Chamber of Commerce (PACC), we have built a dynamic platform where leaders, innovators, and changemakers come together to tackle the most pressing challenges of today while unlocking the opportunities of tomorrow. Our mission is to empower businesses, foster entrepreneurship, and promote sustainable economic growth across Africa and globally.

We offer an array of impactful programs, events, summits, and global initiatives designed to foster growth, build partnerships, and drive innovation. Some of our key upcoming initiatives include:

üåç The African Mayors Conference on Entrepreneurship ‚Äì Bringing together mayors from across South Africa, Africa, the EU, and the US to create sustainable city-level strategies for entrepreneurship and economic development.

Whether you're a large corporation looking to make an impact, an SMME eager to grow, a government entity focused on policy and innovation, or a passionate individual wanting to contribute to Africa‚Äôs progress ‚Äì there‚Äôs a place for you in our Chamber.

Hoy se inicia la semana de Conferencias.

The World Economic Forum 2025 meeting began yesterday in Davos.
Today begins the week of Conferences.

As a Strategic Intelligence Membership, I attach the link to view the Conferences that I consider most important.

This 2025 is a very interesting year. https://lnkd.in/dZHij5Sv Welcoming Remarks and Special Address weforum.org Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Akira Dheena Software Engineer | Artificial Intelligence | Woman in STEM 5mo Edited Report this post Today‚Äôs welcome address at the SingularityU South Africa Summit 2024 by Dr. Peter Diamandis was nothing short of eye-opening! His insights on exponential mindsets, longevity, and the power of like-minded communities truly resonated with me. üå±üß†

He emphasized how finding a community of innovators and disruptors can reshape your mindset at any point in life‚Äîallowing you to think bigger, adapt faster, and continuously evolve. This shift in mindset can lead to more progress in the next decade than we‚Äôve seen in the past century. üåç‚ö°

Dr. Diamandis also delved into the fascinating possibilities of extending longevity and how advancing technologies will push human potential to unprecedented levels. üí°

The potential is limitless, and this is just the beginning. üöÄ Old Mutual South Africa #OldMutual21 #ExponentialMindset #ExponentialAfrica #Longevity #Innovation #TechForGood #FutureProofAfrica #FutureThinking 9 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Andreas Grape Founder and CEO @ Nordic Angels | European Angels | Davos Angels | Podcast Host ‚ÄùPatric blir √Ñngel‚Äù I The State of European Angels I Angel Prize I Mingla.io I ACAP I Nordisia I Secondry 2mo Report this post Davos Angelsü™Ω


Europe can no longer afford a fragmented business community. Fragmentation holds Europe back, and by uniting, business angels we can leverage competence, experience, and capital to unlock network effects, drive growth, and secure Europe‚Äôs position on the global stage

Individual investors have some influence, but as a group, business angels have immense power‚Äîperhaps the most significant untapped resource in Europe. Its a forgotten group that no one has built anything for before on their own terms.

Business angels are a critical voice for innovation, but they lack an independent organization to represent them in the media and to policymakers.

If we come together as a group, entrepreneurs will gain better access to capital. The capital is here in our region, but there‚Äôs a lack of coordination. If we solve that, entrepreneurs can focus on building their businesses instead of searching for capital in every corner of the world.

If you are in Davos during WEF let us know and we might have something for you. Dm please if you are around Thursday where will gather some of the most recognized Angels in Europe. Nordic Angels Ash Pournouri Mark Turrell unDavos Summit Global Conversations Finnish Flow Swedish Lunch Krim Talia Peter Westford Janna Salokangas Mattia Mor Gunhild Anker Stordalen #worldeconomicforum #wef In the picture, I had the pleasure of taking a stroll with Micael Dahlen (the happy professor) during the Swedish lunch last year, together with Alexander Widegren and Marcus Widegren * An unforgettable moment as the children of Klosters raced down the snowy slopes, their laughter and joy filling the crisp winter air, while we grown-ups had a serious conversation about the meaning of happinessüòÖü§£ 377 38 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Oliver Fortune Chikodzore Investor Relations, Regional Integration, Business Strategist, Author, Global Trade and Global Speaker 3mo Report this post Have you ever heard of the crab-bucket effect? The minute you start to ascend in life, the other crabs in the bucket pull you back down‚Äîso you can be trapped in mediocrity with them. It‚Äôs driven by jealousy, envy, resentment, or all three.
 
 Imagine the very opposite effect‚Äîwhere other high achievers are lifting you up to join them in pursuit of your dream.¬†
 You‚Äôve probably heard that you‚Äôre the average of the 5 people you spend the most time with. Where do you find these winners? How do you get around people who can both relate to having a grand vision but also raise the bar for what is possible?
 They flock to specific groups and events (birds of a feather flock together) like business conferences. ABLIS 2025 will help form¬†part of our tribe you need to elevate yourself to the next level. 
Join the Movement
Whether you are a policymaker, investor, entrepreneur, or business leader, ABLIS 2025 offers a unique convergence and marketplace to:
Gain strategic insights into Africa‚Äôs economic opportunities.
Forge lasting collaborations for shared prosperity.
Shape the future of African business and leadership.
Visit www.theablis.com for more information and registration details.
Together, let‚Äôs create a unified, thriving Africa‚Äîa continent poised for innovation, resilience, and collective success. #DestinationRwanda | #ABLIS2025 | #AdvancingAfrica For media inquiries, contact:

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Chris Dyrda‚Äôs Post Chris Dyrda Director First Nations Bank of Canada, Board Chair CHEO Research Institute 3mo Report this post A great piece here about a great contributor to the Indigenous economy. Indigenomics 4,887 followers 3mo Edited The Indigenomics Institute is thrilled to highlight the First Nations Bank of Canada , a distinguished recipient of the Indigenomics 10 to Watch 2024 Award!

Established in 1996, First Nations Bank of Canada (FNBC) is the only Indigenous-owned Schedule 1 bank in the country. Bill Lomax , CEO, emphasizes the bank‚Äôs unique position in the financial sector. "We‚Äôre part of the financial aspect of nation-building," he explains. The bank doesn‚Äôt just offer generic services; instead, it works closely with Indigenous communities to understand and meet their specific needs. FNBC prides itself on tailoring solutions to the priorities of the nations it serves, which distinguishes it from larger commercial banks. 

Beyond financing, FNBC also plays a crucial role in helping Indigenous communities manage their financial assets. It works closely with First Nations on trust management, supporting communities as they manage settlements and other financial resources in a sustainable way. This is Indigenomics in action.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gs69-i9d #Indigenomics #Indigenomics10towatch #Indigenousprosperity #Economicreconciliation #Indigenousbusiness 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Indigenomics 4,887 followers 3mo Edited Report this post The Indigenomics Institute is thrilled to highlight the First Nations Bank of Canada , a distinguished recipient of the Indigenomics 10 to Watch 2024 Award!

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/gs69-i9d #Indigenomics #Indigenomics10towatch #Indigenousprosperity #Economicreconciliation #Indigenousbusiness 59 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Alaa Abdel-Rahman Advisor to the Minister of Finance for International Financial Institutions at Ministry of Finance | Egypt 5mo Report this post ü§ì I had the pleasure of attending a high-level panel during the 9th Ad hoc committee on establishing an African Credit Rating Agency(AfCRA), organised by the Africa Peer Review Mechanism (APRM) and hosted by the Central Bank of Egypt, the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa and the African Development Bank. 

üåç I raised a few points regarding how AfCRA can help in the economic development of the African Continent: enhance the credit worthiness of our collective economies, reduce the credit rating bias that impose higher-than-normal credit risk premia, encourage the development of African domestic capital markets and foster regional integration among our collective markets in the continent. 

ü§ñ I also touched upon how AfCRA can innovate to stay ahead of evolving financial landscape such as leveraging technology and AI drive data and analysis, providing Africa-centric variables and dynamics in the analysis and create a digital platform for stakeholder engagement, among other points. These will help improve credit rating accuracy by analyzing a large quantum of economic, social and environmental data in realtime, all the while providing investors and researchers a more accurate assessment of African credit risks and dynamics. 

‚òëÔ∏è Eventually, Africa has a lot of potential and as a continent, can contribute significantly to economic development and innovation. More data driven analysis, clearer and more transparent communication and a proactive approach to controlling the narrative of our domestic economies, can make or break the economic development we so long to see happen for our lovely and dear continent #Africa #RatingAgencies #SDGs #EconomicDevelopment #FreePalestine #HandsOffLebanon #EndZionism ‚Ä¶more 116 11 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Oswald (Truthonthetrack) Hellemun oswald hellemun 10mo Report this post Rise and shine! üåû Staying humble & staying positive today. Brics 'NDB -toezeggingen Brl 5.7B aan Rio Grande do Sul State miragenews.com Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Samuel Goitom Investment Readiness Officer 6mo Report this post üåç High-Level Dialogue on Africa Credit Rating Agency üåç

Last night at 8 PM, I had the privilege of virtually attending the High-Level Dialogue on the Establishment of the Africa Credit Rating Agency (AfCRA) in New York. This pivotal event, organized by the African Peer Review Mechanism (APRM) and the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA), tackled the pressing issue of unfair credit ratings for African nations.

My key takeaway? The establishment of AfCRA is a game-changer, poised to unlock Africa‚Äôs true economic potential by providing fairer credit ratings. This initiative will pave the way for better access to global capital markets and lower borrowing costs, fuelling Africa‚Äôs industrialization and economic resilience.

However, a well-known challenge remains: How will AfCRA ensure its ratings are accepted and trusted by global investors and financial institutions? This question is crucial for AfCRA‚Äôs success in the realistic world. #AfCRA #EconomicGrowth #AfricaRising #FairCreditRatings #GlobalFinance 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ashley E. Chang Head of Media Relations & Spokesperson at The Rockefeller Foundation 1mo Report this post ‚ÄúThis is by far the largest, most significant public-private partnership to create jobs and stability and hope and opportunity in sub-Saharan Africa,‚Äù Rajiv J. Shah , president of The Rockefeller Foundation , said at the Mission 300 African Energy Summit in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Bloomberg News Antony Sguazzin sums it up, ‚ÄúDubbed Mission 300, the initiative involves pledges from the The World Bank and African Development Bank Group that will be spent on projects across sub-Saharan Africa in return for countries putting in place regulations to attract private investment. Including private capital, and assistance from philanthropies such as the Rockefeller Foundation, the program could see expenditure of as much as $85 billion, although it was difficult to give a precise estimate,‚Äù Ajay Banga, the World Bank‚Äôs president, said in an interview. Settler Ally. üçÅ 2y Report this post Thank you Carol Anne Hilton, MBA for the generous gift of your time and knowledge today.  It was an honor and pleasure to have you in our midst. #indigenomics #reconciliation #knowledge üí°üìñüôè John McKenzie 2y Today, I was grateful to welcome Carol Anne Hilton ‚Äî Founder of the Indigenomics Institute and author of Donner Prize-finalist, 'Indigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table' ‚Äî to the TMX Market Centre.

Carol Anne graciously met with our team and presented an outstanding talk about bringing attention and focus to the growing Indigenous economy. In Carol Anne‚Äôs words, Indigenous economic growth is good for everyone. 

I also had the opportunity to thank Carol Anne, personally for naming TMX Group to the 2022 Indigenomics Top 10 to Watch List, recognizing our efforts towards Indigenous reconciliation and inclusion. 

Carol Anne, on behalf of #TeamTMX , thank you for joining us today. We are so thankful for this opportunity to learn more about the Indigenomics Institute and to have you help us kick off Indigenous History Month at TMX. 17 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Kathy Madigan 2y Report this comment Great presentation. #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics | Nationsfirst Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Nationsfirst‚Äôs Post Nationsfirst 465 followers 9mo Report this post The Indian Act, established in 1876 by the Canadian government, was not designed to honor or leverage the economic wealth of Indigenous peoples. Instead, it was primarily set up as a tool for assimilation and control, imposing European governance structures, restricting Indigenous rights, and undermining traditional economic and social systems. This Act centralized decision-making by Canada, disempowering Indigenous communities and disconnecting them from their traditional governance and economic practices, which were deeply intertwined with their cultural and spiritual beliefs. 

To truly move towards self-determination, Indigenous communities may need to unlearn the systems imposed by the Indian Act and re-engage with their traditional ways. This involves revitalizing Indigenous legal systems and cultural practices and may include adopting modern technologies such as blockchain. Utilizing blockchain could provide transparent and secure methods for managing community resources and transactions, potentially even supporting the creation of a value-based currency that reflects Indigenous values and priorities. Such steps are fundamental in re-establishing Indigenous economic systems and governance structures on their terms and according to their traditional laws and practices. #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics ‚Ä¶more 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Ethan Clark CEO & Co-Founder at Nationsfirst Technologies 9mo Report this post Now is a critical time in our history as Indigenous peoples. We stand at a crossroads, faced with the pivotal decision of whether we will determine our own governance and governments, or allow the colonial government to continue doing so through modern treaty agreements, ‚Äúself-government‚Äù agreements and land management acts. The emergence of blockchain technology presents a transformative opportunity to not only re-establish our sovereignty but also to ensure it remains immutable and incorruptible.

By leveraging blockchain, we can create a transparent and secure foundation for our governance structures, financial systems, and communal investments. This technology allows us to protect our cultural heritage, uphold our traditional laws, and manage our resources in a way that aligns with our values and needs.

Blockchain's decentralized nature empowers us to bypass the colonial frameworks that have historically undermined our self-determination. It offers a means to build a future where our governance is truly representative of our people, and where our decisions are made free from external interference.

At Nationsfirst, we are committed to harnessing this technology to pave the way for a new era of Indigenous sovereignty. Join us as we embark on this transformative journey to reclaim our identity, wealth, and culture. Learn more at www.nationsfirst.io and sign up to be the first to know when we launch. Such steps are fundamental in re-establishing Indigenous economic systems and governance structures on their terms and according to their traditional laws and practices. #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in #KALAKOVERSE NEWS 1,050 followers 5mo Report this post üî• BREAK-THE-WEB !! üî• #KD : üéôÔ∏è~ ‚Äò Hi folks,
I am Kevin Douglas. 

As I mentioned in my last interview in Duba, in my novels, I try to simplify certain concepts.
In #KALAKO for example, Blockchain was one of the most exciting concepts to demystify.

** Let us all transport ourselves in spirit to an African village. Imagine the blockchain as a parley tree, under which villagers gather to make important decisions.¬†üëÅÔ∏è
¬†
ü•ä Instead of all decisions being made by a chief, each and everyone has a say in the matter, and the decision is made together. 

üñêüèº - This is what is called ¬´¬†decentralization in blockchain¬†¬ª: everyone has a role to play and no one controls everything ! ¬¥ ‚öíÔ∏è
¬†
** Now imagine that every time a decision is made under the parley tree, it is engraved in the bark of the tree. ü¶†

‚òÇÔ∏è - This way, everyone will be able to see what has been decided and no one will be able to erase or modify the marks. This is what is called ¬´¬†immutability in blockchain¬†¬ª: once information is added, it cannot be changed.¬†üôèüèæ
¬†
** Additionally, whenever a new decision is carved into the tree, it is linked to all previous decisions. If someone tries to change a previous decision, it will affect all subsequent decisions, which will be easily noticed by everyone. 

‚öîÔ∏è - This is the ¬´¬†hash effect¬†¬ª: a function that links all the blocks together in the blockchain.¬†‚åöÔ∏è
¬†
üç© ~ Furthermore, before a decision is carved into the bark of the tree, everyone must agree. 

- This is what is called ¬´¬†blockchain consensus¬†¬ª: everyone must verify and approve a piece of¬† information before it can be added.¬†‚åõÔ∏è
¬†
** Finally, imagine that there is an oracle in this village who predicts the weather in the coming days. If his predictions come true, he receives a payment. 

üíé - This is similar to ¬´¬†proof of work¬†¬ª in blockchain, where those who solve a complex problem (like predicting the weather) are rewarded. 

** In fact, the blockchain is like a digital parley tree ü¶† ‚Ä¶ where everyone has to express themselves, where all decisions are engraved so that everyone can see them, and where everyone must give their agreement before a new decision can be made. ü•ä #Tech #A .i #KD #KALAKOTV #ADMP #DLT #Delhi #Dubai #Doha #Lubumbashi #ManUtd #LaurynHill #FashionWeek ‚Ä¶more 7 5 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Anthony Richard CEO of Universe.com | Leader | Innovator | Blockchain, Web3 and AI Technology enthusiast | Strategist | Futurist | Building for Africa 3mo Report this post We are in the last month of the year!

It has been an interesting year and we can not deny that we have a lot to say about it.

Am pleased to share that we have been finally incorporated by the Nigerian government as a company at UNIVERSE.COM under the name; 

UNIVERSE CONNECT ENTERPRISE AFRICA LTD

It was long 8 months of waiting to get this and over the course, we had to change our names three times after they had been approved.

Patience kept us because that delayed us in getting some certain things done. None the less, we are a resilient set of people and we are determined on our goals.

We are determined to contribute greatly to the growth of the African economy, this is the climax of our passion, to shape the African economy at large and to prove to the world that Africa has what it takes to live sustainably and become an economic giant of a continent through connecting and providing sustainable and inclusive solutions first to local problems and then internationally.

Blockchain and cryptocurrency is key to unlocking the new economy. Any nation determined to leverage it, is on the verge of economic breakthrough.

Not leaving AI, for now, there are few people or entities building AI, any other person else is just applying as a tool, but in a short while, we shall be showing what it means to truly build A blockchain and AI tech solutions, that is another level entirely!

Am so excited at what we can do with the right support, resources and talents. 

I am a futurist, I innovate for the future.

The Constitution allocates specific powers to both, allowing states to cater to regional needs while ensuring national unity. However, political bargaining and regional demands can sometimes challenge this balance, just as we see with the tension between centralization and decentralization in the tech world.

In tech, decentralization, such as with blockchain, empowers individual nodes or systems to function independently while maintaining security and transparency across the network. This is similar to how states operate in a federal system: they have the autonomy to address local issues but are part of the larger national framework. Decentralization fosters innovation, resilience, and responsiveness, allowing each unit to adapt to its unique context.

The key, both in governance and tech, is finding the right balance. The strength lies in decentralization‚Äôs ability to innovate and adapt, while also ensuring coordination and unity in a larger system. #Federalism #Innovation #Politics #BalanceofPower #Technology #Decentralization 13 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ivan B. Linde Sustainability Technology Liaison | Open to GREAT Collaboration Opportunities | Open Networker LION 5mo Report this post ### Tether's Bold Move: Boron-Backed Tokens in Turkey 

In an ambitious effort to integrate blockchain technology beyond traditional uses, Tether has approached the Turkish government with a cutting-edge proposal: digital tokens backed by boron. This initiative reflects Tether's aim to extend its stablecoin influence, exploring the utility of natural resources like boron in stabilizing digital currencies. By leveraging blockchain, Tether seeks to offer a transparent and efficient system that taps into Turkey's boron-rich reserves, potentially revolutionizing how value is transferred and stored.

The collaboration with Turkey underscores the company's strategic vision to innovate in the stablecoin market by exploring unique asset-backing options. Tether envisions this partnership as a path to both strengthen the digital currency ecosystem in Turkey and present a model that could be replicated globally. The utilization of boron, a high-demand mineral with diverse applications, underlines a commitment to sustainability and resource-backed financial solutions.

This proposal comes at a time when countries are increasingly exploring digital currencies' potential to reshape their financial landscapes. If realized, Tether‚Äôs boron-backed tokens could offer Turkey a robust new vehicle for economic development, securing a future where digital and physical assets coalesce seamlessly.

Title: TELUS's reconciliation strategy with Indigenous communities
Description: Mar 14, 2024  ¬∑  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x¬†...

#10towatch #indigenomics #telus #indigenousbusinesses‚Ä¶ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚Äôs User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D‚Äôs Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Report this post ‚ÄúConnectivity is the foundation of our reconciliation strategy. We know that reliable access to technology supports Indigenous Peoples‚Äô access to education, career opportunities, healthcare, and social support. TELUS is committed to bringing connectivity to more Indigenous communities working closely with Indigenous governments and organizations, along with provincial and federal governments,‚Äù shares Marissa Nobauer , Director of Reconciliation, Community Engagement and External Relations.

Today we are shining a spotlight on TELUS, who is recognized as a distinguished recipient on the 2023 Indigenomics #10TOWATCH List.

TELUS is taking significant strides in supporting Indigenous communities through their multi-faceted reconciliation strategy. Their reconciliation strategy is co-designed with Indigenous communities, focusing on fostering relationships grounded in Indigenous Ways of Knowing and supporting Indigenous Youth and communities.

Here's a glimpse of their initiatives:

‚Ä¢	Connectivity: Providing high-speed internet access to over 197 Indigenous communities and aiming to connect 20 more Indigenous lands, recognizing its crucial role in education, healthcare, and economic opportunities.
‚Ä¢	Investing in Indigenous Businesses: Striving for 7.5% investment in Indigenous-owned businesses by 2026 through their Pollinator Fund and actively increasing procurement spending with them.
‚Ä¢	Empowering Indigenous Women: Expanding their Mobility for Good program to support Indigenous women facing violence.

TELUS' dedication to Indigenous empowerment shines through their initiatives. 

Learn more about their impactful work at: https://lnkd.in/e2YEnaqu #Indigenomics #TELUS #Indigenousbusinesses #Indigenousprosperity #IndigenousLeaders #Economicreconciliation #Indigenouseconomy #100billiondollarIndigenouseconomy 72 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Ilie Efros Director of Sales | Managed & Professional Network Services 11mo Report this comment TELUS's commitment to connectivity and Indigenous empowerment is truly inspiring, paving the way for meaningful change! I hope it encourages other large and small corporations to be brave and play their role in advancing reconciliation. Thank you! üôå

EF-Tu \(elongation factor thermo unstable\) is a prokaryotic elongation factor responsible for catalyzing the binding of an aminoacyl-tRNA \(aa-tRNA\) to the ribosome. It is a G-protein, and facilitates the selection and binding of an aa-tRNA to the A-site of the ribosome. As a reflection of its crucial role in translation, EF-Tu is one of the most abundant and highly conserved proteins in prokaryotes.

Research from academics like Gene Fama revealed that markets efficiently price in all available information, making traditional stock-picking ineffective. This breakthrough paved the way for index funds and the democratization of investing, allowing anyone to capture market returns without speculation.
